definition:
Indicate the hemoglobin (Hgb) value in g/dL.

Note(s):  
This may include POC (Point of Care) testing results or results obtained prior to arrival at this facility.
question: Please clarify which lab result is coded when both a Point-of-Care (POC) test and traditional lab are drawn at the same time.
answer: When the lab DRAW time is equal for both POC and Lab run specimens, the registry would have you code the laboratory processed specimen as the pre-procedure lab value.

definition:
Indicate the hemoglobin (Hgb) value in g/dL.

Note(s):  
This may include POC (Point of Care) testing results or results obtained prior to arrival at this facility.
question: A patient is diagnosed with STEMI by EMS and is immediately transported to the cath lab for emergent PCI upon arrival.  The procedure start time is 0856 and labs are drawn immediately upon access at 0900.  Please clarify if these labs can be used for 'Pre-Procedure' lab values.
answer:
When the patient condition/emergent presentation results in pre-procedure labs being drawn in the cath lab, it IS acceptable to code these results IF the specimens were obtained immediately upon access and prior to anticoagulation administration. 
Additional Information:
Biomarkers obtained in this way would not influence coding for the Seq# 7400 (Indication for Cath Lab Visit) as they were obtained after the patient had arrived in the cath lab and thus would not have influenced decision making.

definition:
Indicate if the patient was prescribed or received the medication.

Note(s):
Code 'No' if a patient was given a sublingual, IV, or short acting formula of one of these medications.

Code 'Yes' if the patient received an oral (long-acting formula) of the medication after admission but prior to this cath lab visit.
question: Please clarify the target value of Seq# 6991 (Pre-Procedure Medication Administered) which is “any occurrence between 2 weeks prior to current procedure and current procedure."
answer:
Sequence #6991 (Pre-Procedure Medications Administered) captures medications that were prescribed OR administered to the patient within the 2 weeks prior to AND up to the start of current procedure. 
All medications the patient was prescribed prior to arrival (regardless of the patient’s compliance) as well as medications the patient received at your facility prior to the cath lab procedure should be captured.
Provider documentation of a medical reason as to why a medication was not prescribed supports coding ‘Contraindicated’ in Seq# 6991.  
Exception:
In scenarios where a pre-procedure medication is ordered (prescribed) in the hospital BUT is not administered to the patient, please code ‘No’.

element_name: Family History of Premature Coronary Artery Disease
definition:
Indicate if the patient has a family history of premature coronary artery disease.

Note(s):  
If the patient is adopted, or the family history is unknown, code 'No'.

Family history includes any direct blood relatives (parents, siblings, children) who have had any of the following diagnosed at age less than 55 years for male relatives or less than 65 years for female relatives

1. Angina

2. Acute myocardial infarction

3. Sudden cardiac death without obvious cause

4. Coronary artery bypass graft surgery

5. Percutaneous coronary intervention
question: Provider documentation indicates there is a  "family history of premature CAD".  Is this sufficient to support coding "Yes" in Seq#4287 (Family History of Premature Coronary Artery Disease)?
answer:
Yes. The Registry has  clarified that 'Yes' can be coded for Seq#4287 (Family History of Premature Coronary Artery Disease)  when there is documentation of “family history of premature coronary artery disease” or when the supporting definition is met:                                                                                                             
Family history includes any direct blood relatives (parents, siblings, children)who have had any of the following diagnosed at age less than 55 years formale relatives or less than 65 years for female relatives
1. Angina
2. Acute myocardial infarction
3. Sudden cardiac death without obvious cause
4. Coronary artery bypass graft surgery
5. Percutaneous coronary intervention

definition:
Indicate the patient symptoms or condition prompting the cath lab visit.

Note(s): 
The Cath Lab Indications collected in this field by your application are controlled by Cath Lab Indication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: What is used to determine the timeframe <=24 hrs and >24hrs for the “ACS” Cath Lab Indications in Seq#7400?
answer:
The time lapse from ACS diagnosis to cath lab presentation should guide which selection is indicated.  



To clarify: Because the definition is focused on when the patient “has” ACS (unstable angina, NSTEMI or STEMI), please use the diagnosis date/time.

definition: Indicate the dominance of the coronary anatomy (whether the posterior descending artery comes from the right or left vessel system).
question: Frequently, coronary dominance is not documented on a subsequent admission for PCI.  When that is the case and the target value "any occurrence between 30 days prior to the procedure and the procedure" isn't met, must I leave the data element blank?
answer:
Because 'dominance' does not change, the registry will accept a value for Seq#7500 (Dominance) from information found in a medical record that is  >30 days prior to the procedure.



EXCEPTION: if the patient has a history of a heart transplant, please ensure dominance is coded to reflect the new heart.

definition:
Indicate the reason the percutaneous coronary intervention PCI is being performed.

Note(s): 
The PCI Indications collected in this field by your application are controlled by PCI Indication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: What is used to determine the PCI Indication (Seq#7825) timeframe <= 12 hrs and >12 hrs for patients not having “Immediate PCI for STEMI”?
answer: The time lapse from the symptom date/time coded in Seq#7826/7827 to PCI presentation should guide which select is indicated.

definition:
Indicate the date and time the patient noted ischemic symptoms lasting greater than or equal to 10 minutes.

Note(s):
Symptoms may include jaw pain, arm pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, fatigue/malaise, or other equivalent discomfort suggestive of a myocardial infarction.
question: A patient c/o two-day intermittent chest pain, waking this morning at 5am with chest pain, plus nausea and diaphoresis.  STEMI is diagnosed on arrival to ED and “Immediate PCI for STEMI” is selected as the PCI Indication (Seq#7825).  What date/time are coded for Seq#7826/7827 (Symptom Date/Time)?
answer: Please indicate today’s date at 5am.  Per the target value, this is the “last” value prior to the procedure.

definition:
Indicate the time the patient first noted ischemic symptoms lasting greater than or equal to 10 minutes.    

Note(s):
Indicate the time (hours:minutes) using the military 24-hour clock, beginning at midnight (00:00 hours).

If the symptom time is not specified in the medical record, it may be recorded as 0700 for morning; 1200 for lunchtime; 1500 for afternoon; 1800 for dinnertime; 2200 for evening and 0300 if awakened from sleep.
question: A patient c/o two-day intermittent chest pain, waking this morning at 5am with chest pain, plus nausea and diaphoresis.  STEMI is diagnosed on arrival to ED and “Immediate PCI for STEMI” is selected as the PCI Indication (Seq#7825).  What date/time are coded for Seq#7826/7827 (Symptom Date/Time)?
answer: Please indicate today’s date at 5am.  Per the target value, this is the “last” value prior to the procedure.

definition: Indicate the type of intervention or surgery that occurred.
question: The patient requires a surgical arterial repair (for an access site injury).  I coded "Yes" in Seq#10030 (Interventions this Hospitalization).  How do I capture this intervention in Seq#10031?
answer:
Please select "Other" in Seq#10031 to capture this occurrence.<br&g

Additional information: 

In this scenario, 'Other Vascular Complications Requiring Treatment' is also coded in Seq# 9001/9002.

definition: Indicate the lesion location using the coronary artery segment diagram of the native lesion.
question: The patient’s 4th OM has an 80% stenosis but that is no such option on the coronary anatomy diagram, how should this lesion be captured?
answer: Please ask the provider to indicate which segment on the coronary anatomy diagram best represents the location of the patient’s lesion, you or they should add an amendment in the medical record indicating their response to support coding. If working with the provider is unsuccessful, the registry has agreed that segment 22 – 3rd obtuse marginal branch can be coded in Seq#7507 (Native Vessel Segment Number), 7527 (Graft Vessel Segment Number), or 8001 (PCI Segment Number) as applicable to the scenario.

element_name: Cardiac Arrest Out of Healthcare Facility
definition: Indicate if a cardiac arrest event occurred outside of any healthcare facility.
question: I coded "Yes" to Seq#4630 (Cardiac Arrest Out of Healthcare Facility).  How do I code the child fields (Seq#'s 4631, 4632, 4633) when a patient suffers multiple occurrences of cardiac arrest outside of a healthcare facility?
answer: Please code the child fields (Seq#'s 4631, 4632, 4633) of Seq#4630 (Cardiac Arrest Out of Healthcare Facility) to reflect the initial "first" cardiac arrest.

definition:
Indicate the findings of the electrocardiac assessment.

Note(s): Select all abnormal electrocardiac findings that meet the definition and/or are supported by physician diagnosis.
question: A patient's ECG on arrival shows STEMI.  "Abnormal" was coded in Seq#5032 (EC Assessment Results).  Which selection would apply in Seq#5034 (EC Abnormality Type)?
answer: The diagnosis of STEMI supports capturing "ST deviation >= 0.5mm" in Seq#5034 (EC Abnormality Type).

definition: Indicate if a non-invasive stress test was performed.
question: Can you explain how to apply the target value “last value between birth (or previous procedure) and current procedure” for Seq#5200 (Stress Test Performed)?
answer:
When the target value is separated into two distinct thoughts, it is easier to apply to the patient scenario.
;• When the patient presents for a new episode of care, apply this portion of the target value: “Last value between birth and current procedure” 
;• When the patient presents to the cath lab after having a diagnostic coronary angio and/or PCI during the episode of care, apply this portion of the target value: “Last value between previous procedure and current procedure”
;*Exception: When the patient has had ONLY a diagnostic cath and presents for PCI in a second cath lab visit, it is acceptable to capture the stress test and results for both procedures.

definition: Indicate if a cardiac arrest event occurred at this facility PRIOR to the cath lab visit.
question: A patient arrives to the cath lab for their procedure and has a cardiac arrest as the procedure is getting underway.  Would this event be captured in Seq#7340 (Cardiac Arrest at this facility)?
answer:
Please code “Yes” to Seq#7340 (Cardiac Arrest at this Facility) with the understanding that cardiac arrest occurred prior to local anesthetic administration or vascular access being obtained, which would mark the ‘start’ of the procedure (as coded in Seq#7000).
In scenarios where cardiac arrest has occurred after the start of the procedure, then it is captured as an “Intra and Post Procedure Event” in Seq#9001.

definition:
Indicate the patient symptoms or condition prompting the cath lab visit.

Note(s): 
The Cath Lab Indications collected in this field by your application are controlled by Cath Lab Indication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: A patient c/o two-day persistent chest pain that is worse with exertion, nausea and diaphoresis. The patient has no prior history of CAD or angina. Initial ECG reveals NSTEMI and the patient is transferred to the cath lab. What is coded for Seq#7400 (Indications for Cath Lab Visit)?
answer: Because the patient has no history of angina but has experienced this for two days, the definition is met for ‘New onset angina <= 2months’.  Without a history of CAD >=50% stenosis, the definition is met for ‘Suspected CAD’.  Lastly, the diagnosis of NSTEMI and timing of presentation meets the definition for ‘ACS <= 24 hrs’.

definition:
Indicate if there was written documentation of a referral for the patient (by the physician, nurse, or other personnel) to an outpatient cardiac rehabilitation program, or a documented medical or patient-centered reason why such a referral was not made.

The program may include a traditional cardiac rehabilitation program based on face-to-face interactions and training sessions or may include other options such as home-based approaches.
question: If a PCI patient leaves AMA (Against Medical Advice), do we leave Seq#10116 (Cardiac Rehab) blank?
answer:
Please code "No - Reason Not Documented" in Seq#10116 when a patient leaves the facility against medical advice.  
Additionally:  Please always follow coding instructions and guidance and allow the Metrics to apply exclusion criteria accordingly.

definition:
Indicate if the patient had a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) attempted and/or performed during this cath lab visit.     

Note(s):  

Code 'Yes' when a guidewire is introduced for the purpose of PCI.

A percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is the placement of an angioplasty guide wire, balloon, or other device (e.g. stent, atherectomy, brachytherapy, or thrombectomy catheter) into a native coronary artery or coronary artery bypass graft for the purpose of mechanical coronary revascularization.
question: A diagnostic angiogram reveals a significant stenosis that the operator decides to treat. The operator passes the interventional guidewire through the guide catheter, but is unable to advance the wire into the target vessel. The decision is made to abort the procedure. How is Seq# 7050 (PCI) coded?
answer: As clarified in the data dictionary 'note' for this data element, please code 'Yes' in Seq# 7050 (PCI) whenever a guidewire is introduced (inserted into the patient) for the purposes of PCI. The registry captures all PCI procedures attempted and/or performed.

definition: Indicate if the patient has been diagnosed with heart failure.
question: There is no documentation of heart failure diagnosis in the medical record; however, the provider documents 'NYHA Class II' prior to the procedure. Is this acceptable to code "Yes" for Seq#4001 (Heart Failure)?
answer: Please code 'Yes' for Seq#4001 (Heart Failure). The diagnosis of heart failure is understood when an NYHA class is documented in the medical record to meet the target value of "any occurrence between birth and current procedure."

definition:
Indicate the patient symptoms or condition prompting the cath lab visit.

Note(s): 
The Cath Lab Indications collected in this field by your application are controlled by Cath Lab Indication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: A patient is being evaluated for possible TAVR and therefore, "Valvular Disease" is identified as one of the indications coded in Seq# 7400.  Would  "Pre-operative Evaluation" also be coded in this scenario?
answer: Please only capture “Valvular Disease” in Seq#7400 with respect to the valve disease and TAVR indication.  A patient being evaluated for a  minimally-invasive procedure such as TAVR, would not qualify as receiving pre-operative 'cardiac clearance' and therefore,  the definition for "Pre-operative Evaluation" is not met in Seq#7400 (Indications for Cath Lab Visit).

definition: Indicate the segment(s) that the current lesion spans (a lesion can span one or more segments).
question: PCI was performed on a  Left Main stenosis of 80%.  There is no documentation identifying which LM segment was treated.  Which segment would I identify in Seq#8001 (Segment Number)?
answer: When the specific segment of the LM is NOT identified, the CathPCI Steering Committee has agreed that 'Distal left main" (11c) can be selected when PCI of the LM also involves either/both of the Ostium (proximal portion) of the LAD or Circumflex.  If the proximal portion of either/both the LAD or Circumflex are not involved in the LM PCI, please code 'Proximal left main' (11a).   Please continue to work with your clinicians to accurately depict the patient's coronary anatomy for registry purposes.

definition: Indicate if the patient had a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), prior to this admission.
question: How is Seq# 4495 (Prior PCI) coded when a patient had an unsuccessful PCI prior to the current episode of care?
answer: Please code ‘yes’ to Seq# 4495 as the registry includes both attempted and performed PCIs in the data definition. Once a guide wire is inserted for the purpose of mechanical revascularization, ‘yes’ is coded.

definition:
Indicate if the patient has a history of chronic lung disease.

Note(s):
A history of chronic inhalation reactive disease (asbestosis, mesothelioma, black lung disease or pneumoconiosis) may qualify as chronic lung disease. Radiation induced pneumonitis or radiation fibrosis also qualifies as chronic lung disease. A history of atelectasis is a transient condition and does not qualify.
question: Please provide examples of what constitutes chronic lung disease for coding Seq# 4576.
answer:
Seq# 4576 captures chronic lung disease processes such as COPD, emphysema, interstitial lung disease and sarcoidosis (when there is lung involvement). 




Conditions which involve the respiratory system that are not considered ‘chronic’ by the registry are asthma, lung cancer and tuberculosis. As well, sleep apnea and pulmonary hypertension do not qualify as chronic lung disease.

definition:
Indicate the Troponin I result in ng/mL.
 
Note(s): 
This may include POC (Point of Care) testing results.
question: What is coded in Seq# 6090 (Pre-Procedure Troponin) when documentation states the troponin is ‘<0.01’?
answer: When a numerical value is documented as ‘<’ or ‘>’, please code the next lowest (or highest) number to that value (that conforms to the decimal place designated in the technical specifications for the data element). Therefore, a troponin value "<0.01" would be captured as "0.00" in Seq# 6090 (Pre-procedure Troponin).

definition:
Indicate the patient symptoms or condition prompting the cath lab visit.

Note(s): 
The Cath Lab Indications collected in this field by your application are controlled by Cath Lab Indication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: A patient with a history of CABG 5 years ago has been having atypical angina for the past 6 weeks and presents for coronary angiography.  There is no documentation indicating the patient has ever had angina before, even prior to CABG surgery.  Is it appropriate to code “New Onset Angina <= 2 months” for Seq#7400 (Indications for Cath Lab Visit) in this scenario?
answer: No, please capture the patient’s recent atypical angina as “Worsening Angina” in Seq#7400.  Documentation of prior MI, PCI or CABG are understood by the registry to identify the patient has a history of cardiac ischemia equivalent to angina.

definition:
Indicate the pre-intervention TIMI flow.

Note(s):  If a lesion spans multiple segments with different TIMI flow, code the lowest TIMI flow within the entire lesion.
question: When a lesion has 100% stenosis and TIMI flow is not documented, can ‘0’ be coded for Seq#8007 (TIMI Flow Pre-Intervention)?
answer:
Yes. Because the lesion is 100% it is understood to obstruct all antegrade flow and ‘0’ can be coded for Seq#8007 (TIMI Flow Pre-Intervention).  
Note: The intent of the TIMI flow grading system is to categorize antegrade flow, perfusion from collaterals should not be counted when evaluating TIMI flow.

definition:
Indicate the patient's Health Insurance Claim (HIC) number.

Note(s):
Enter the Health Insurance Claim (HIC) number for those patients covered by Medicare. Patients with other insurances will not have a HIC number.
question: Please clarify if it is OK to code either HIC or MBI numbers in Seq#3015.
answer: It is acceptable to code the Medicare Beneficiary Identifier (MBI) in Seq#3015 (Health Insurance Claim Number) field until a specific field for the MBI number is added to the v5 dataset.  If you encounter any issues coding this number, please contact us for further assistance.

definition: Indicate if a non-invasive stress test was performed.
question: When a PET scan is performed to evaluate cardiac disease, can "Yes" be coded in Seq#5200 (Stress Test Performed)?
answer: If the cardiac disease evaluation by PET scan involved a 'stress component', then 'Yes' can be coded for Seq#5200 (Stress Test Performed) and the study identified by selecting 'Stress Nuclear" in Seq#5201.

definition: Indicate the most recent date of the stress test.
question: Please clarify how to code Seq#5204 (Most Recent Date of Stress Test) when it is not clearly documented in the medical record.
answer:
When capturing historical data for data elements that require a date, and the month/day is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/yyyy. If the year is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/estimated year.  If this information cannot be found in the medical record or clarified with the physician, it can be left blank. However, this may affect passing the DQR.  

This guidance is applicable to all data elements capturing historical data.

definition:
Indicate the ending date and time at which the operator completes the procedure and breaks scrub at the end of the procedure.

Note(s):
If more than one operator is involved in the case then use the date and time the last operator breaks scrub for the last time.
question: What is acceptable documentation to use to identify the end of the procedure?
answer: Seq#7005 (Procedure End Date/Time) seeks to capture the date/time the operator broke scrub for the last time.  Documentation that indicates this has transpired will support coding (e.g. physician broke scrub, MD completed the procedure, case end).  If this occurrence is not clear in the documentation, please code the time the patient left the procedure room.

definition:
Indicate if any native vessel had a lesion >= 50%.

Note(s): 
Identify the disease found in vessels >=2mm.

Identify disease found in vessels <2mm when PCI is intended for the lesion and/or the patients anatomy is <2mm.

It is acceptable to use prior cath lab visit information, as long as there have been no changes in coronary anatomy. This includes stenosis determined via cardiac catheterization at another facility. This does not include collaterals.

Stenosis represents the percentage diameter reduction, ranging from 0 to 100, associated with the identified vessels. Percent stenosis at its maximal point is estimated to be the amount of reduction in the diameter of the "normal" reference vessel proximal to the lesion. In instances where multiple lesions are present, enter the single highest percent stenosis noted.
question: Please clarify if native vessel stenosis of 99% is captured when the vessel has been bypassed by a bypass graft.
answer:
When any coronary vessel has stenosis of >=50%, please identify this in the coronary anatomy section.  For this scenario, 'Yes' is coded for Seq#7505 (Native Vessel with Stenosis >=50%) and the specific segment identified in Seq#7507 (Native Lesion Segment Number) and 99% coded in Seq#7508 (Native Stenosis).  



To Clarify:  Please capture all disease >=50% that is assessed on the current procedure and/or document within the previous 6 months if there have been no changes to the diseased segment (discussed in the notes section).

definition: Indicate the lesion location using the coronary artery segment diagram of the native lesion.
question: How are two distinct stenoses, of 70% and 90% respectively, captured in the coronary anatomy section when they are found in the same coronary segment (i.e. Mid LAD/Segment 13)?
answer:
The segment number (13) is identified in Seq#7507 (or 7527) and the ‘most severe percent stenosis in the segment’ (in this case 90%) is identified in Seq#7508 (or 7528). 
  


Note: A segment number should only appear once in either Seq#7507 (Native Lesion Segment Number) or Seq#7527 (Graft Lesion Segment Number).  Please do not capture the segment number twice.

definition: Indicate if an invasive diagnostic measurement was obtained of the native vessel segment.
question: The physician documented use of IVUS during the procedure to the 2nd diag and LAD.  There is no documentation of any measurements in the cath lab procedure log or elsewhere in the medical record.  How should this be captured in Seq#7511 (Adjunctive Measurements Obtained)?
answer: When IVUS or OCT is utilized and there is no MLA value obtained and subsequently reported/documented, then it will be necessary to  code "No" to Seq#7511 (Native Vessel Adjunctive Measurements Obtained) as the coding instructions are to indicate if an invasive diagnostic measurement was 'obtained'.

definition: Indicate which medications were administered.
question: Is it acceptable to  identify medications administered to a patient  still on the procedure table as "procedure medications" even though it is after the procedure has "ended" (as coded in Seq#7005)?
answer: For the purposes of the CathPCI Registry,  it is acceptable to code "Yes" to any medication administered to the patient while they are in  the cath lab procedure room in Seq#7995 (PCI Procedure Medications).

definition: Indicate the segment(s) that the current lesion spans (a lesion can span one or more segments).
question: How are two distinct stenosis, of 70% and 90% respectively, captured when they receive PCI and are found in the same coronary segment (i.e. Mid LAD/Segment 13)?
answer:
The segment number (13) is identified in Seq#8001 and the ‘highest value’ stenosis (in this case 90%) is identified in Seq#8004 (Stenosis Immediately Prior to Rx).   



Note: A segment number should only appear once in Seq#8001 (Segment Number).  Please do not capture the segment number twice under different lesion counters.

element_name: Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure without intervention
definition:
Indicate if the patient had a prior diagnostic coronary angiography procedure without a subsequent intervention.

Note(s): 
Code “No” if the patient's previous diagnostic coronary angiogram occurred at the transferring facility and the patient presents for PCI.

Code "No"  if the most recent cath lab visit involved PCI.
question: Please explain how to apply the target value “any occurrence between birth (or previous procedure) and current procedure” for Seq. 5263 (Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiogram without Intervention).
answer:
The goal of the registry is to understand whether the patient had an intervention (PCI or CABG) after the MOST RECENT diagnostic coronary angiogram. The target value is very broad and with the parenthetical statement is ‘covering all the bases’, it is easier to understand if broken down into two distinct thoughts, applying each thought to the unique patient scenario and, remembering the goal is to understand what happened after the most recent or last diagnostic coronary angiogram:
• If the patient presents from home, the target value is ‘between birth and current procedure’
• If the patient is already in your facility and presents after a cath lab procedure, the target value is ‘between previous procedure and current procedure’

definition:
Indicate if any native vessel had a lesion >= 50%.

Note(s): 
Identify the disease found in vessels >=2mm.

Identify disease found in vessels <2mm when PCI is intended for the lesion and/or the patients anatomy is <2mm.

It is acceptable to use prior cath lab visit information, as long as there have been no changes in coronary anatomy. This includes stenosis determined via cardiac catheterization at another facility. This does not include collaterals.

Stenosis represents the percentage diameter reduction, ranging from 0 to 100, associated with the identified vessels. Percent stenosis at its maximal point is estimated to be the amount of reduction in the diameter of the "normal" reference vessel proximal to the lesion. In instances where multiple lesions are present, enter the single highest percent stenosis noted.
question: The patient has a 100% occluded 1st Diagonal, it is noted in the medical record on an angiogram which was performed 2 years ago, and it was not reassessed during the current procedure; can this known total occlusion be captured in the coronary artery section?
answer:
Yes. The Steering Committee has agreed that previously validated 100% occlusions (that have never received PCI) may not warrant reassessment yet remain part of the patient’s coronary artery disease burden and can be captured despite the target value in the coronary anatomy section (i.e., Seq# 7505, 7507, 7508) of “last value between 6 months prior to current procedure and current procedure”.

This guidance is applicable to Seq# 7507 and Seq# 7508.

definition:
Indicate if any graft vessel had a lesion >= 50%.

Note(s):
Identify the disease found in vessels >=2mm.

Identify disease found in vessels <2mm when PCI is intended for the lesion and/or the patients anatomy is <2m.

It is acceptable to use prior cath lab visit information, as long as there have been no changes in coronary anatomy. This includes stenosis determined via cardiac catheterization at another facility. This does not include collaterals.

Stenosis represents the percentage diameter reduction, ranging from 0 to 100, associated with the identified vessels. Percent stenosis at its maximal point is estimated to be the amount of reduction in the diameter of the "normal" reference vessel proximal to the lesion. In instances where multiple lesions are present, enter the single highest percent stenosis noted.
question: The patient has a 100% occluded SVG to the 1st Diagonal, it is noted in the medical record on an angiogram which was performed 2 years ago, and it was not reassessed during the current procedure; can this known total occlusion be captured in the coronary artery section?
answer:
Yes. The Steering Committee has agreed that previously validated 100% occlusions (that have never received PCI) may not warrant reassessment yet remain part of the patient’s coronary artery disease burden and can be captured despite the target value in the coronary anatomy section (i.e., Seq# 7525, 7527, 7528) of “last value between 6 months prior to current procedure and current procedure”.

This guidance is applicable to Seq# 7527 and Seq# 7528.

definition: Indicate if the previously treated lesion was treated with any type of stent in the current or prior episode of care.
question: When a lesion was previously treated with a stent, but the stent did not occur in the most recent treatment date, is 'no' coded in Seq# 8010 (treated with stent)?
answer: Seq# 8010 (treated with stent) is a child field of Seq# 8008 (previously treated lesion); however, it is not a child field of Seq# 8009 (previously treated lesion date). This allows you to code 'yes' to Seq# 8010 if the lesion has EVER been treated with a stent; it does not have to be the most recent treatment date. This is appreciated by viewing the hard-copy data collection form.

definition: Indicate the hemoglobin (Hgb) value in g/dL.
question: Since the target value of Seq# 8505 (post-procedure hemoglobin) is, 'the lowest value between current procedure and 72 hours after current procedure,' may values drawn after discharge but within 72 hours be used for coding?
answer: No. The hemoglobin value must be drawn at your facility, during the same episode of care. The registry has noted to change this target value to, ‘the lowest value between current procedure and 72 hours after current procedure or discharge,’ in the next version upgrade.

definition: Indicate if the medication was prescribed, not prescribed, or was not prescribed for either a medical or patient reason.
question: How is Entresto (sacubitril/valsartan) captured in Seq# 10205 (discharge medications prescribed)?
answer: Please code ‘yes’ to ARB in Seq# 10205 when Entresto is prescribed at discharge. The registry currently does not have a coding selection for neprilysin inhibitors.

definition: Indicate if a non-invasive stress test was performed.
question: How is Seq# 5200 (Stress Test Performed) coded when the study is terminated prior to initiation of the ‘stress’ portion, due to evidence of ischemia (e.g. patient experiences chest pain symptoms and/or ischemic ECG changes)?
answer:
“Yes” is coded in Seq# 5200 (Stress Test Performed) and stress test type captured accordingly in Seq# 5201 (Stress Test Performed Type).  



Additional Information:  In the absence of provider documentation indicating a stress test result, the registry understands the evidence of ischemia to support coding “Positive” in Seq# 5202 (Stress Test Result).

definition:
Indicate the patient's heart rate (beats per minute).

Note(s): During atrial fibrillation code the ventricular rate.
question: A patient presents with new onset atrial fibrillation.  The patient is cardioverted to NSR and then presents for their cath lab visit.   How is Seq# 6011 (Heart Rate) coded? With the patient's heart rate when they were in atrial fibrillation or the last documented heart rate after cardioversion to normal sinus rhythm?
answer: As a child field of Seq# 5034 (EC Abnormality Type), and specific to when "New Onset Atrial Fib" is collected, the intent of Seq# 6011 (Heart Rate) is to capture the last value (heart rate) prior to the procedure, when the patient's rhythm was in atrial fibrillation.

definition: Indicate the chest pain symptom assessment as diagnosed by the physician or described by the patient.
question: The physician has diagnosed the patient with "Unstable Angina" and "CCS IV".  There is no additional documentation to support coding the definitions "Typical Angina" or "Atypical Angina".  How should I code Seq# 7405 (Chest Pain Symptom Assessment)
answer:
In the absence of descriptive documentation of the patient’s chest pain symptoms that meets an anginal selection definition (typical or atypical), the CathPCI Registry has agreed that documentation of "Unstable Angina" and/or "CCS Class IV" supports coding "Typical Angina" in Seq# 7405 as these designations signify the 'highest' available selections.

Essentially, the guiding principle in capturing Seq# 7405 (Chest Pain Symptom Assessment) is to:
1.            Identify if the definition for an anginal selection is met (i.e. patient has Atypical Angina supports coding "Atypical Angina"). 
2.            If this documentation, is not available, then identify descriptive documentation that meets an anginal selection definition (Patient has anginal pain w/exertion, relieved w/rest meets the definition and supports coding "Typical Angina").
3.            If the documentation does not support an anginal selection, please apply this ACD to support coding.

definition: Indicate the chest pain symptom assessment as diagnosed by the physician or described by the patient.
question: Can documentation of angina CCS IV be captured in Seq#7405 (Chest Pain Symptom Assessment)?
answer:
In the absence of descriptive documentation of the patient’s chest pain symptoms that meets an anginal selection definition (typical or atypical), documentation of CCS IV will support coding “typical angina” in Seq#7405 (Chest Pain Symptom Assessment). As well, documentation of CCS I, II or III will supporting coding “atypical angina”. *Please continue to educate your physicians on the coding selections and definitions used by the “chest pain symptom assessment” field; these selections are utilized by the updated AUC.


Essentially, the guiding principle in capturing Seq# 7405 (Chest Pain Symptom Assessment) is to:

1.	Identify if the definition for an anginal selection is met (i.e. patient has Atypical Angina supports coding "Atypical Angina"). 
2.	If this documentation, is not available, then identify descriptive documentation that meets an anginal selection definition (Patient has anginal pain w/exertion, relieved w/rest meets the definition and supports coding "Typical Angina").
3.	If the documentation does not support an anginal selection, please apply this ACD to support coding.

definition: Indicate the chest pain symptom assessment as diagnosed by the physician or described by the patient.
question: A patient presents to the ED with 8/10 chest pain and is diagnosed with STEMI.  There is no additional documentation in the medical record indicating if it is provoked by exertion, relieved by rest, nitro, etc…How do I code Seq#7405 (Chest Pain Symptom Assessment)?
answer:
In the absence of descriptive documentation of the patient’s chest pain symptoms that meets a different chest pain symptom assessment selection,  the registry has agreed "Typical Angina" can be selected for Seq#7405 when there is/has been chest pain associated with the STEMI presentation.

Essentially, the guiding principle in capturing Seq# 7405 (Chest Pain Symptom Assessment) is to:

1.  Identify if the definition for an anginal selection is met (i.e. patient has Atypical Angina supports coding "Atypical Angina"). 
2.  If this documentation, is not available, then identify descriptive documentation that meets an anginal selection definition (Patient has anginal pain w/exertion, relieved w/rest meets the definition and supports coding "Typical Angina").
3.  If the documentation does not support an anginal selection, please apply this ACD to support coding.

definition:
The lesion counter is used to distinguish between multiple lesions on which a PCI is attempted or performed.

When specifying intracoronary devices, list all treated lesions in which the device was utilized.

Note(s):
The software-assigned lesion counter should start at one and be incremented by one for each lesion. The lesion counter is reset back to one for each new PCI lab visit.

At least one lesion must be specified for each PCI procedure.
question: A patient receives PCI to their Proximal LAD and Mid LAD. The stents do not overlap. In Seq#8000 (Lesion Counter) and Seq#8001 (Segment Number), do I capture this as one lesion with two segments or two separate lesions?
answer:
Treated segments/areas that are sequential to one another, (as with a Proximal LAD, Mid LAD, etc.) are generally considered one lesion in Seq#8000 (Lesion Counter) with the segment(s) identified in Seq#8001 (Segment Number). "Overlapping" stents are not required to support coding this way.

** Exception:  When provider documentation clearly depicts the sequentially treated segments as separate lesions, we will defer to the provider’s representation to support coding.  While the registry encourages that sequentially treated segments be captured as one lesion, please capture the lesion(s) that best reflects provider documentation.

definition: Indicate the most recent date a cardiac computerized tomographic angiography (CTA) was performed.
question: Please clarify how to code Seq# 5226 (Cardiac CTA Date) when it is not clearly documented in the medical record.
answer:
When capturing historical data for data elements that require a date, and the month/day is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/yyyy. If the year is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/estimated year.  If this information cannot be found in the medical record or clarified with the physician, it can be left blank. However, this may affect passing the DQR.

This guidance is applicable to all data elements capturing historical data.

definition: Indicate the most recent date of the agatston calcium score.
question: Please clarify how to code Seq#5257 (Agatston Calcium Score Date) when it is not clearly documented in the medical record.
answer:
When capturing historical data for data elements that require a date, and the month/day is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/yyyy. If the year is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/estimated year.  If this information cannot be found in the medical record or clarified with the physician, it can be left blank. However, this may affect passing the DQR.

This guidance is applicable to all data elements capturing historical data.

element_name: Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure Date
definition: Indicate the date of the prior diagnostic coronary angiography.
question: Please clarify how to code Seq#5264 (Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure Date) when it is not clearly documented in the medical record.
answer:
When capturing historical data for data elements that require a date, and the month/day is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/yyyy. If the year is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/estimated year.  If this information cannot be found in the medical record or clarified with the physician, it can be left blank. However, this may affect passing the DQR.  

This guidance is applicable to all data elements capturing historical data.

definition:
Indicate if the patient has had at least one documented previous myocardial infarction.

Note(s): 
Code 'No' if the patient's only MI occurred at the transferring facility.

 Code 'Yes' if the patient's only MI occurred at the transferring facility but it was treated with PCI or CABG prior to arrival at this facility
question: When the patient has received a heart transplant, how are historical data elements (capturing the specific cardiac history of the patient) coded?
answer: Please code Seq#4291 (Prior MI) and Seq#4001 (Heart Failure) to reflect the status of the new heart.  Please complete Seq#4495 (Prior PCI) and Seq#4515 (Prior CABG) to reflect the patient’s history.

definition: Indicate the type of tobacco product the patient uses.
question: Are vaping products and e-cigarettes considered tobacco products when coding Seq#4626 (Tobacco Type)?
answer: For Seq#4626 (Tobacco Type), E-cigarettes and vaping products are not captured in this data element as they are nicotine delivery devices, not tobacco.

element_name: Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure without intervention
definition:
Indicate if the patient had a prior diagnostic coronary angiography procedure without a subsequent intervention.

Note(s): 
Code “No” if the patient's previous diagnostic coronary angiogram occurred at the transferring facility and the patient presents for PCI.

Code "No"  if the most recent cath lab visit involved PCI.
question: Could you clarify how to code Seq#5263 (Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure without Intervention) when the patient has a diagnostic ‘only’ cath lab visit and PCI is deferred to another day during the hospitalization/episode of care?
answer:
When PCI is planned based on the diagnostic cath, please code ‘No’ for Seq#5263 (Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography WITHOUT Intervention).

This data element seeks to identify when an intervention (PCI/CABG) was not the intended treatment after the diagnostic cath.

definition:
Indicate if the patient was prescribed or received the medication.

Note(s):
Code 'No' if a patient was given a sublingual, IV, or short acting formula of one of these medications.

Code 'Yes' if the patient received an oral (long-acting formula) of the medication after admission but prior to this cath lab visit.
question: Several medications such as the Calcium Channel Blockers and Beta Blockers are administered for Anti-Anginal and Antiarrhythmic indications. Should these medications be  in a single category or multiple?
answer: Please only identify one medication category for each medication.  Example: Sotalol is a beta blocker by definition; it does have antiarrhythmic properties, but the actual class is beta blocker.  The same logic is applied to verapamil and diltiazem; they are coded as Ca Channel Blockers in Seq#6991 (Pre-Procedure Medications).

definition: Indicate which medications were administered.
question: Does Intra-arterial (IA) heparin count as a procedure medication in Seq#7995 (Procedure Medications Administered)?
answer:
Please capture any Heparin administered between 24 hours prior to current procedure and end of current procedure Seq#7995 (Procedure Medications Administered), regardless of dose/route. 



***** The EXCEPTION ***** 
Heparin that is part of a 'Heparin Flush' is NOT captured

definition:
Indicate if there was severe calcification of the lesion.

Note(s): To support coding there must documentation of 'severe calcification' specific to the lesion treated during the PCI procedure, by the interventionalist.
question: Must the documentation state the lesion has “severe calcification” or is there any other acceptable documentation that will support coding ‘Yes’ for Seq#8021 (Severe Calcification)?
answer: The registry agrees the following words are synonymous with “severe” and will supporting coding ‘Yes’ for Seq#8021 (Severe Calcification):  extreme; heavy; critical.

definition:
Indicate the date and time the event occurred.

Note(s):
Indicate the time (hours:minutes) using the military 24-hour clock, beginning at midnight (00:00 hours). 

If an event occurred more than once on the same date, record the event multiple times with the same date.

If an event occurred more than once in the target timeframe but on different dates, record the event multiple times but with unique dates.
question: Please advise how best to capture the date/time of an Intra or Post-Procedure Event in Seq#9003 (Intra and Post Procedure Event Date/Time).
answer: Please indicate the earliest date and time of the occurrence as documented by the provider, the test result identifying the occurrence, or the treatment initiated to treat the occurrence.

definition:
Indicate the creatinine (Cr) level mg/dL.

A discharge creatinine is coded when there are multiple post‐procedure specimens (to support coding both the post‐procedure & discharge data elements) or when the (single) specimen obtained does not meet the post‐procedure target value.

*Do not code the results from a single specimen in both post‐procedure and discharge data element fields
question: The patient has multiple creatinine values post-procedure; the HIGHEST value (1.5), drawn 5 days after procedure, is the LAST value drawn.  Therefore, this specimen meets the target value for Seq#8510 (Post-Procedure Creatinine).  Should this SINGLE specimen be captured as BOTH the post-procedure and discharge creatinine in Seq#10060 (Discharge Creatinine)?
answer:
This specimen will only be coded in Seq#8510 (Post-Procedure Creatinine); then 'Not Drawn' is captured in Seq#10661 (Discharge Creatinine Not Drawn).

To Clarify:  The first note in Seq#10060 specifies that coding a discharge creatinine occurs when there are multiple post-procedure labs; however, the second note clarifies that the results from a single specimen should not be coded in both the post-procedure and discharge data element fields.  This advice is applicable to this scenario.   The discharge creatinine field is intended to capture a unique specimen.

definition: Indicate the specific medication classes that were reconciled.
question: Can you provide guidance on how medications are captured in Seq#10221 (Reconciled Medications) and how to code when a medication is applicable to two or more categories, as we can "select all that apply”?
answer:
Please only select one medication category for each medication.  Then apply the following:


• Prescription: Cardiac – medications that are recognized to have a direct cardiac benefit (i.e. statins, beta blockers, diuretics, antihypertensives, antiarrhythmics, anticoagulants, etc.)


• Prescriptions:  Non-cardiac – medications that treat non-cardiac diseases (i.e. drugs for diabetes, arthritis, cancer)


• Over the Counter (OTC) Medications – whether prescribed or not, if the medication is available ‘over the counter’, select this option (i.e. aspirin, fish oil, antacids)


• Vitamins/Minerals – whether prescribed or not, this option includes supplements that are categorized as vitamins or minerals (i.e. folic acid, zinc, etc.)


• Herbal Supplements – whether prescribed or not, this option includes supplements that originate from herbs (i.e. cranberry, gingko, echinacea, etc.)

definition: Indicate the specific medication classes that were reconciled.
question: How is Fish Oil captured in Seq#10221 (Reconciled Medications)?
answer: Because fish oil is available over-the-counter, whether it is prescribed or not, please select "Over the Counter" in Seq#10221 (Reconciled Medications).  You may find ACD 24855 helpful.

definition:
Indicate the date and time the patient arrived at your facility.

Note(s):
Indicate the time (hours:minutes) using the military 24-hour clock, beginning at midnight (00:00 hours).
question: Question: What documentation is used to determine arrival date and time?
answer: The registry has aligned with Chest Pain- MI registry in that the earliest time of arrival as documented by the facility is coded in Seq# 3001.

definition:
Indicate the patient symptoms or condition prompting the cath lab visit.

Note(s): 
The Cath Lab Indications collected in this field by your application are controlled by Cath Lab Indication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: Question: How do I capture STEMI/NSTEMI which occurred >7 days prior to the cath lab visit?
answer:
A STEMI/NSTEMI which is diagnosed >7 days prior to the cath lab visit is considered ‘over’ by the registry and may no longer be captured as the cath lab or PCI indication. Please only code current symptoms/conditions prompting the cath lab visit. 
Additionally:
You may code ‘yes’ to Seq# 4291 (prior MI) in this scenario as the STEMI/NSTEMI is now considered a historical event. Please note that for patients whose STEMI/NSTEMI is diagnosed at your facility and 7 days transpires before their cath lab procedure, this guidance represents an exception to the target value of “any occurrence between birth and arrival at this facility”.
Additional information: Seq# 4296 (prior MI date) is left blank to accommodate the MI that is now considered 'history'.

definition:
Indicate the event that occurred between the procedure and the next procedure or discharge.

Note(s): Multiple instances of the same event may be identified if the event occurred more than once during the target timeframe.
question: Question: Must all adverse events and PRBC transfusions be coded for the entire length of stay, regardless of how long the patient remains in our facility?
answer:
If the procedure was a diagnostic ‘only’, the registry has agreed it is acceptable to limit coding of events and transfusions to 30 days when the post-procedure length of stay is > 30 days.
If the procedure was PCI, AND the facility is not engaged in collecting follow-up data, the registry has agreed it is acceptable to limit coding of events and transfusions to 30 days when the post-procedure length of stay is 
> 30 days.

definition: Indicate the direct identifier portion of the Unique Device Identifier (UDI) associated with the closure method utilized. This ID is provided by the device manufacturer, and is either a GTIN or HIBC number.
question: Please explain what I should code in Seq#7333 (Closure Method Unique Device Identifier).
answer: At this time, Seq#7333 (Closure Method Unique Device Identifier) is reserved for future use.  Please leave this data element blank.  Doing so will not cause any issues when submitting through the DQR.

definition:
Indicate the patient symptoms or condition prompting the cath lab visit.

Note(s): 
The Cath Lab Indications collected in this field by your application are controlled by Cath Lab Indication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: A patient diagnosed with “Unstable Angina” 5 days ago, presents electively for a diagnostic cath.  The patient has a hx of angina and “Worsening Angina” has been coded in Seq#7400 (Indications for Cath Lab Visit).  Is it also acceptable to select "ACS > 24 hrs"?
answer: Because the patient presents “electively”, our understanding is they are not “acute” nor is their angina equal to an “Acute Coronary Syndrome” (based on the information provided).  Please do not select “ACS > 24 hrs” for this scenario.  If there is any doubt, please discuss with the physician.

definition: Indicate the direct identifier portion of the Unique Device Identifier (UDI) associated with the intracoronary device. This ID is provided by the device manufacturer, and is either a GTIN or HIBC number.
question: Please explain what I should code in Seq#8029(Intracoronary Device Unique Identifier).
answer: At this time, Seq#8029 (Intracoronary Unique Device Identifier) is reserved for future use.  Please leave this data element blank.  Doing so will not cause any issues when submitting through the DQR.

definition: Indicate if the transfusion occurred during or after surgery.
question: A hybrid approach (PCI & CABG) is utilized to treat the patient’s CAD.  PCI is performed on day #1 and CABG on Day #2.  One unit of PRBC is administered on day #3, within 72 hours of the both the PCI & CABG.  How are Seq#9277 (Transfusion PCI) and Seq#9278 (Transfusion Surgery) coded?
answer: Please code 'Yes' for both Seq#9277 (Transfusion PCI) and Seq#9278 (Transfusion Surgical) as the target values of "any occurrence between start of procedure and 72 hours after current procedure" are met.

definition: Indicate if the transfusion occurred during or after surgery.
question: Please clarify the term 'procedure' in the target value for Seq#9278 (Tansfusion Surgery), which states "any occurrence between start of procedure and 72 hours after current procedure."
answer: For Seq#9278 (Transfusion Surgery), the 'procedure' is understood to mean surgery in the context of the coding instructions, which state "indicate if the transfusion occurred during or after surgery."

element_name: Percutaneous Coronary Intervention of the Left Main Coronary Artery
definition: Indicate if the patient's prior PCI included revascularization of the Left Main.
question: Does Seq#4501 (Left Main PCI) pertain only to the most recent PCI coded in Seq#4503 (Most Recent PCI Date)?
answer:
No.  Please code 'Yes' in Seq#4501 when a patient has history of PCI of the left main coronary artery, meeting the target value of "any occurrence between birth and arrival at this facility."
To clarify:  Please refer to the data collection form to appreciate that Seq#4501 (Left Main PCI) is a child field to Seq#4495 (Prior PCI). It is not a child field to Seq#4503 (Most Recent PCI Date).

definition:
Indicate the arterial closure methods used in chronological order regardless of whether or not they provided hemostasis. The same closure method may be repeated.

Note(s):
If multiple access sites were utilized during the procedure, only provide those closure methods used for the site identified in Element Ref# 7320 (Arterial Access Site).

The closure method devices that should be collected in your application are controlled by a Closure Method Device Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: How is a TR band used on the radial artery captured in Seq#7331 (Arterial Access Closure Method)?
answer: Please code ‘Mechanical Compression’ in Seq#7331 when a TR band is used to attempt and/or achieve hemostasis.

definition: Indicate if there was a transfusion(s) of packed red blood cells.
question: Is autologous blood transfused during a surgical procedure captured in Seq#9275 (RBC Transfusion)?
answer: No. The CathPCI Registry does not capture cell saver/auto-transfusions.

definition: Indicate if the patient has systolic or diastolic heart failure.
question: How should Seq#4013 (Heart Failure Type) be coded when there is a diagnosis of combined systolic/diastolic HF (there isn't a 'both' option)?
answer: For the purposes of the CathPCI Registry, only one heart failure 'type' can be selected based on the definition as found in the data dictionary full specifications.  If the EF is >=50%, then 'Diastolic' would be selected.  If the EF is <50%, then 'Systolic' would be selected.

element_name: Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure without intervention
definition:
Indicate if the patient had a prior diagnostic coronary angiography procedure without a subsequent intervention.

Note(s): 
Code “No” if the patient's previous diagnostic coronary angiogram occurred at the transferring facility and the patient presents for PCI.

Code "No"  if the most recent cath lab visit involved PCI.
question: How is Seq#5263 (Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure Without Intervention) coded when a patient presents to our hospital for PCI after CAD was discovered during a diagnostic catheterization at an outlying facility?
answer: Please code "No" as the diagnostic angiogram at the other facility has identified disease that is 'subsequenttly' being treated with an 'intervention' at your facility.

definition:
Indicate the mechanical ventricular support device used.

Note(s):
The device that should be collected in your application are controlled by a Mechanical Ventricular Support Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: A patient had an Impella device placed at the start of the procedure.  However, during the PCI portion of the procedure, the mechanical support device was changed to ECMO.  Which device is captured in Seq#7423 (Mechanical Ventricular Support Device)?
answer: For Seq#7423 (Mechanical Ventricular Support Device), if multiple mechanical support devices are used on the current procedure,  please capture the 'highest' level of support.  In the given scenario, the 'highest' level of support would be ECMO.

definition: Indicate when the mechanical ventricular support device was placed.
question: A patient had an Impella device placed at the start of the procedure.  However, during the PCI portion of the procedure, the mechanical support device was changed to ECMO.  As 'ECMO'  is considered the device providing the 'highest' level of support during the procedure, ECMO was selected in Seq#7423 (Mechanical Ventricular Support Device).  How should Seq#7424 (Mechanical Ventricular Support Timing) be completed, as the target value is "Any occurrence on current procedure"?
answer: Because the coding instructions are to "capture when the mechanical ventricular support device was placed", please select the timing that identifies when the first mechanical support was utilized.  For this scenario, please code  “Inserted during the procedure and prior to  intervention”.

definition:
Indicate if the PCI procedure was performed in the presence of multi-vessel disease.

Note(s):
Code 'Yes' if this is the initial (first) PCI procedure for the cath lab indication and the patient has obstructive disease >=70% stenosis in >=2 coronary vessels and/or disease 50%-70% stenosis in >=2 coronary vessels with non-invasive or FFR/IFR evidence of ischemia in that territory and/or left main disease >=50% stenosis.
(A coronary vessel is defined as: LAD and any of its branches, LCX and any of its branches, RCA and any of its branches, a true RAMUS branch >2 mm)

Code 'Yes' if this is a subsequent, planned staged PCI procedure of a vessel not treated during the initial PCI procedure.  The first PCI could have been during a prior admission, or during this admission but must occur within 90 days of the initial PCI procedure.
question: When PCI is performed on a single stenosed vessel and the only additional disease found is a 100% occluded native vessel that had been bypassed, is this considered "PCI for MultVessel Disease."?
answer: No.  Native coronary vessels that have been bypassed are not considered when capturing this data element unless PCI will be attempted and/or performed on the native coronary vessel during the procedure.

definition:
Indicate the event that occurred between the procedure and the next procedure or discharge.

Note(s): Multiple instances of the same event may be identified if the event occurred more than once during the target timeframe.
question: When a patient has coffee ground emesis pre-procedure and was actively bleeding post-procedure, does this qualify as an intra/post procedure GI bleed?
answer:
Please code ‘No’ for “Gastrointestinal” bleeding in Seq#9001 (Intra and Post-Procedure Events) and include this notation in your Data Dictionary for future reference:

A patient who was actively bleeding with coffee ground emesis pre-procedure would not qualify as having intra/post-procedure bleeding.  However, a patient with peptic ulcer disease with no noted or active bleeding prior to the procedure who starts bleeding during/after the procedure would qualify and ‘yes’ should be coded.

definition:
Indicate if there was written documentation of a referral for the patient (by the physician, nurse, or other personnel) to an outpatient cardiac rehabilitation program, or a documented medical or patient-centered reason why such a referral was not made.

The program may include a traditional cardiac rehabilitation program based on face-to-face interactions and training sessions or may include other options such as home-based approaches.
question: When a patient receives a cardiac rehab referral after their initial PCI/hospitalization and returns to the hospital for staged PCI, is the previous cardiac rehab referral provided sufficient to code 'Yes' for Seq#10116 (Cardiac Rehab Referral)?
answer: The cardiac rehab referral provided to the patient after the first PCI procedure is not sufficient to code 'Yes' for this hospitalization.  In order to code 'Yes' for Seq#10116 (Cardiac Rehabilitation Referral) in scenarios where the patient has been attending cardiac rehab, there must be documentation, at the time of discharge, indicating the patient is to continue their current cardiac rehab program.  When there is no documentation to continue cardiac rehab or implementing a new order for cardiac rehab at the time of discharge, please code "No-No Reason Document"

definition: Indicate if another procedure was performed in conjunction with a diagnostic coronary angiography and/or PCI procedure.
question: In order to code “Yes” for Seq# 7065 (Concomitant Procedures Performed), does the procedure need to completed?
answer: No. Please code “Yes” for Seq# 7065 (Concomitant Procedures Performed) whenever a concomitant procedure collected by the registry was attempted and/or performed.

definition: Indicate the chest pain symptom assessment as diagnosed by the physician or described by the patient.
question: Can patient symptoms documented to be an “anginal equivalent” be used to abstract Seq#7405 (Chest Pain Symptom Assessment)?
answer: The documentation must indicate that symptoms represent an “anginal equivalent” AND specify the chest pain symptom type (typical or atypical) they are representative of to support coding Seq#7405 (Chest Pain Symptom Assessment).            *If the chest pain symptom type is not specified and cannot be clarified, please select “atypical”.

element_name: Patient Centered Reason for Delay in PCI
definition:
Indicate if there was a patient-centered reason for delay in performing the percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).

Note(s):
A patient-centered reason for delay is an issue/condition understood and documented to originate  with the patient.  It is not associated with the health care system (i.e. facility, staff or processes, etc.).  

To warrant coding 'Yes' the patient-centered reason(s) must be identified in the first 90min after arrival at this facility or in the first 90min after an in-house diagnosis of STEMI and be responsible for affecting the time to PCI.  

If the issue is documented in the medical record and the effect on timing self-evident, it can be coded.  If the effect on timing/delay to PCI is unclear, then there must be specific documentation by a physician/APN/PA that establishes the linkage between the patient issue/condition and the timing/delay in PCI.
question: A patient is diagnosed with STEMI and requires emergent placement of an RVAD prior to intervention.  Would this qualify as a patient centered reason for delay in PCI?
answer: Please code "Yes" to Seq#7850(Patient Centered Reason for Delay in PCI) when the RVAD is placed emergently in an unstable/symptomatic patient AND there is supporting evidence/documentation that links the event to the delay in PCI.  Then, please code "Emergent placement of LV support device before PCI" in Seq# 7851.  This selection is meant to be inclusive of any emergently-placed ventricular support device (right or left).

element_name: Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure without intervention
definition:
Indicate if the patient had a prior diagnostic coronary angiography procedure without a subsequent intervention.

Note(s): 
Code “No” if the patient's previous diagnostic coronary angiogram occurred at the transferring facility and the patient presents for PCI.

Code "No"  if the most recent cath lab visit involved PCI.
question: How is Seq#5263 “Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure without Intervention” coded when the last diagnostic angiogram showed multi-vessel disease that was subsequently treated with CABG, prior to this cath lab presentation?
answer: Please code “No” for Seq#5263 (Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiograph Procedure without Intervention) for this scenario.     To clarify:  ‘Yes’ is only coded for this data element when the CAD identified during a diagnostic procedure  is NOT subsequently treated with PCI and/or CABG (both PCI and CABG are “interventions” for coronary artery disease).

definition:
Indicate the hemoglobin (Hgb) value in g/dL.

Note(s):  
This may include POC (Point of Care) testing results or results obtained prior to arrival at this facility.
question: The target value states "the last value within 30 days prior to the first procedure in this admission".  Does that mean the same baseline Hgb will be coded for all procedures  during an admission?
answer: Please note the target value for Seq#6030 (Hemoglobin) in incorrectly written in the current data dictionary.  Please code to the target value of "the last value within 30 days prior to the current procedure".  We anticipate this error will be corrected in the data dictionary in the next minor version upgrade.

definition:
Indicate the assigned identification number associated with the medications the patient was prescribed or received.

Note:  The medications that should be collected in your application are controlled by a Medication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application. Each medication in the Medication Master file is assigned a timing indicator. This indicator is used to separate procedural medications from medications prescribed at discharge. The separation of these medications is depicted on the data collection form.
question: What medications, dietary supplements or natural products does the registry recognize as ‘Non-Statins’ for Seq#6986 (Pre-Procedure Medications)?
answer:
Non-statins include drugs that are not in the "statin" class but lower cholesterol; typically these are prescription medications. A list of medications (not all inclusive) that are considered non-statins are: Cholestyramine [Questran; Prevalite; Lo-Cholest], Colesevelam [Welchol] Colestipol [Colestid] Ezetimibe [Ezetrol, Ezemibe, Zetia] Fenofibrate [Tricor; Antra, Lofibra], Gemfibrozil [Lopid], Lovaza or Vascepa (omega-3-acid ethyl esters),Triplex and Nexletol [bempedoic acid]. 

 Dietary supplements or natural products that have cholesterol lowering capabilities such as Niacin, fish oils and nutraceuticals should not be coded as non-statins unless they are high dose supplements taken under the direction of a physician.

definition:
Indicate the best estimate of the current left ventricular ejection fraction.

Note(s):
Enter a percentage in the range of 01 - 99.  If a percentage range was reported, report the lowest number of the range (i.e.50-55%, is reported as 50%).  

If only a descriptive value is reported (i.e.normal), enter the corresponding percentage value from the list below:
Normal = 60%
Good function = 50%
Mildly reduced = 45%
Fair function = 40%
Moderately reduced = 30%
Poor function = 25%
Severely reduced = 20%
question: How is Seq#7060 (Diagnostic Left Heart Cath) and Seq#7061 (LVEF) completed when an LV gram was not performed?
answer: "Yes" should be coded for Seq#7060 (Diagnostic Left Heart Cath) whenever the coding instructions and target value of "the value between start of procedure and PRIOR to the intervention" is met.  When an LV gram was not obtained, please leave Seq#7061 blank.  The threshold for this field has been lowered to 0% to accommodate this frequent occurrence.

definition: Indicate if the patient has cardiovascular instability.  Cardiovascular instability includes, but is not limited to, persistent ischemic symptoms (such as chest pain or ST elevation), cardiogenic shock, ventricular arrhythmias, symptoms of acute heart failure, or hemodynamic instability (not cardiogenic shock).
question: How should the target value of 'value on current procedure' be applied to Seq#7410 (Cardiovascular Instability).
answer: Please identify when cardiovascular instability is 'present prior to the start of the current procedure'.     Note:  Cardiovascular Instability is specific to:  ongoing ischemic symptoms (chest pain, STE), ventricular arrhythmias, acute heart failure symptoms, hemodynamic instability (not cardiogenic shock), cardiogenic shock, refractory cardiogenic shock.

definition:
Indicate the assigned identification number associated with the medications the patient was prescribed upon discharge.

Note(s):
Discharge medications not required for patients who expired, discharged to "Other acute care hospital", "Left against medical advice (AMA)" or are receiving Hospice Care.

The medication(s) collected in this field are controlled by the Medication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application. Each medication in the Medication Master file is assigned to a value set. The value set is used to separate procedural medications from medications prescribed at discharge. The separation of these medications is depicted on the data collection form.
question: What medications, dietary supplements or natural products does the registry recognize as ‘Non-Statins’ for Seq#10200 (Discharge Medications)?
answer:
Non-statins include drugs that are not in the "statin" class but lower cholesterol; typically these are prescription medications. A list of medications (not all inclusive) that can be considered as Other Lipid Lowering Med (Non-Statin) are: Cholestyramine [Questran; Prevalite; Lo-Cholest], Colesevelam [Welchol] Colestipol [Colestid] Ezetimibe [Ezetrol, Ezemibe, Zetia] Fenofibrate [Tricor; Antra, Lofibra, Gemfibrozil [Lopid],Lovaza or Vascepa (omega-3-acid ethyl esters), Triplex, and Nexletol (bempedoic acid). 

Dietary supplements or natural products that have cholesterol lowering capabilities such as Niacin, fish oils and nutraceuticals should not be coded as non-statins unless they are high dose supplements taken under the direction of a physician.

Note:  If Alirocumab and/or Evolocumab (PCSK9 Inhibitors) are prescribed at discharge please do not identify these as a non-statin medications here, instead indicate the applicable selection.

definition:
Indicate if the patient requested for their information not to be used for any research or studies for the associated episode of care.

Note(s):
Documentation must be found in the patient record to support the request of removal of their information.
question: What is the Patient Restriction field and how should it be coded?
answer:
The coding instructions for the Patient Restriction field are as follows:


Indicate if the patient requested for their information not to be used for any research or studies for the associated episode of care.


Note(s): Documentation must be found in the patient record to support the request of removal of their information. 


The Patient Restriction field was implemented to provide patients with a means to effectively “opt-out” of research or studies.  By checking the box, NCDR participants are indicating the patient has 1) formally requested their NCDR data not be used for any research or studies and 2) this request is substantiated by documentation that can be found in the patient’s medical record.  This box should not be checked if either of these is incomplete or missing.  Patients who meet the definition-based criteria are acknowledging that their NCDR data will not be used for any research or studies for that associated episode of care. Checking the box once does not preclude that patient’s NCDR data from being redacted from research or studies for any previous or future episodes of care.


For purposes of clarity, research or study is defined as any systematic investigation (including research development, testing and evaluation) for the purpose of developing or contributing to generalizable knowledge.

definition:
Indicate if the patient had a left heart cath procedure, defined as the passage of a catheter into the left ventricle for the purposes of angiography or measurement of ventricular pressures and/or oxygen saturation.

Note(s):  Code 'No' if the left ventricle was only assessed post-intervention (PCI).
question: If a patient has a left heart cath-only (no PCI or dx coronary angiogram), do we code "Yes" to Seq#7060 (Diagnostic Left Heart Cath)?
answer: Left Heart Cath ONLY procedures are not included in CathPCI v5. Please refer to the Inclusion criteria document: CathPCI Registry>Resources>Documents> v5 Registry Inclusion Criteria

definition:
Indicate the event that occurred between the procedure and the next procedure or discharge.

Note(s): Multiple instances of the same event may be identified if the event occurred more than once during the target timeframe.
question: Would a TIA qualify as a hemorrhagic, ischemic or undetermined stroke in Seq#9001 (Intra & Post-Procedure Events)?
answer: A TIA, which is a transient ischemic event caused by a disruption in blood flow that does not result in injury, does not qualify as a stroke for any of the intra/post-procedure selections.

definition:
Indicate other interventions (percutaneous or surgical) that occurred during this hospitalization. 

Note(s): 
This does not include interventions that occurred during the same cath lab visit as a Diagnostic Cath or PCI procedure.
question: Please provide examples of Intervention Types that would be coded in Seq#10031 (Intervention Type).
answer:
Seq#10030/10031 (Interventions this Hospitalization/Type) seeks to capture 'percutaneous' and 'surgical' interventions.  The location in which the intervention was performed is a key driver in determining the appropriate selection along with the procedure.  Please review:

*       CABG  = surgical procedure: coronary artery bypass graft surgery (only)
*       Cardiac Surgery (non-CABG) = surgical procedure: valve repair/replacement; structural repair, etc. (not involving CABG)
*       Valvular Intervention = non-surgical intervention: transcatheter aortic valve replacement, valvuloplasty
*       Structural Heart Intervention (non-valvular)  = non-surgical intervention: alcohol septal ablation, PFO repair, PDA closure, (or other involving the heart but not the valve)
*       Surgery (non-cardiac) = surgical procedure: hip replacement, cholecystectomy, (or other, not in the heart)
*       EP Study = electrophysiology related procedure (any), ablation, PPM, AICD
*       Other = peripheral intervention, carotid stent

definition: Indicate the type of intervention or surgery that occurred.
question: Please provide examples of Intervention Types that would be coded in Seq#10031 (Intervention Type).
answer:
Seq#'s10030/10031 (Interventions this Hospitalization/Type) seeks to capture 'percutaneous' and 'surgical' interventions.  The location in which the intervention was performed is a key driver in determining the selection along with the procedure.  Please review:

*       CABG  = surgical procedure: coronary artery bypass graft surgery (only)
*       Cardiac Surgery (non-CABG) = surgical procedure: valve repair/replacement; structural repair, etc. (not involving CABG)
*       Valvular Intervention = non-surgical intervention: transcatheter aortic valve replacement, valvuloplasty
*       Structural Heart Intervention (non-valvular)  = non-surgical intervention: alcohol septal ablation, PFO repair, PDA closure, (or other involving the heart but not the valve)
*       Surgery (non-cardiac) = surgical procedure: hip replacement, cholecystectomy, (or other, not in the heart)
*       EP Study = electrophysiology related procedure (any), PPM, AICD
*       Other = peripheral intervention, carotid stent

definition: Indicate the date of the follow-up assessment was performed.
question: Is the entire 'Follow-Up' Section M. optional or is only the Rose Dypnea Scale and Seattle Angina Questionaire (SAQ)?
answer: All of Section M. Follow-Up (pages 12, 13 & 14 of the DCF) is optional and completed at the discretion of the facility.

definition: Indicate the date of the follow-up assessment was performed.
question: Can our facility participate in follow-up for a selected population of patients or must it be completed for ALL patients?
answer: Follow-up data is only collected for patients who had PCI during the Episode of Care.  For facilities engaged in collecting follow-up data, the expectation is that an attempt will be made to contact all eligible patients.  If/when a patient is unable to be reached, please indicate "lost to follow up" for Seq#11004 (Follow-Up Status).

definition:
Indicate the patient symptoms or condition prompting the cath lab visit.

Note(s): 
The Cath Lab Indications collected in this field by your application are controlled by Cath Lab Indication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: The physician documents 'cardiac clearance for endoscopy procedure' as one of the indications for the patient's cath lab visit.  Does this support coding "Pre-Operative Evaluation" in Seq#7400 (Indications for Cath Lab Visit)?
