answer: No.  "Pre-operative Evaluation" in Seq#7400 (Indications for Cath Lab Visit) is specific to capturing those patients who present for cardiac evaluation related to major 'surgical' interventions, as evidenced by the child fields Seq#7465 (Evaluation for Surgery Type), Seq#7466 (Functional Capacity) and Seq#7468 (Surgical Risk), which assess the type of surgery, and surgical appropriateness/risk.

element_name: Patient Transferred In for Immediate PCI for STEMI
definition: Indicate if the patient was transferred from another facility to have a primary PCI for STEMI at this facility.
question: Please clarify what qualifies as a 'facility' per the coding instructions in Seq#7841 (Transferred in for Immediate PCI for STEMI).
answer: Only 'acute care' facilities (hospital or free-standing ED) are captured in this data element. When a patient is transferred from an urgent care center, physician’s office, or any other medical facility, ‘No’ is coded in Seq#7841.

definition:
Indicate if there was written documentation of a referral for the patient (by the physician, nurse, or other personnel) to an outpatient cardiac rehabilitation program, or a documented medical or patient-centered reason why such a referral was not made.

The program may include a traditional cardiac rehabilitation program based on face-to-face interactions and training sessions or may include other options such as home-based approaches.
question: If a referral order for cardiac rehab is made and the patient declines, how is Seq#10116 (Cardiac Rehab Referral) coded?
answer:
When a cardiac rehab referral is made and there is a documented attempt to inform and discuss cardiac rehab with the patient, as well as documentation of the patient's refusal, "Yes" is coded in Seq#10116 (Cardiac Rehab Referral).



To clarify:
Per the 2017 AHA/ACC Clinical Performance and Quality Measures for Adults With ST Elevation
and Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction document: “If documentation in the medical record exists noting that the provider has informed and discussed referral to a cardiac rehabilitation/secondary prevention program with the patient, but that the patient refuses a referral, then the healthcare provider would not be expected to send communication about the patient to the cardiac rehabilitation/secondary prevention program. This is consistent with HIPAA confidentiality regulations and shared decision making, and performance would then be considered met by the provider (preventing unjust penalization of the provider)”.

definition: Indicate the category of the  medication dose prescribed.
question: Simvastatin 80mg is not listed under dose intensity (low, moderate, or high).  How is this medication coded in Seq#10207 (Discharge Medication Dose)?
answer: Because Simvastatin is not recommended to be prescribed at a dose greater than 40mg, please leave Seq#10207 (Discharge Medication Dose) blank when a dose greater than 40 mg is prescribed.

definition: Indicate the category of the  medication dose prescribed.
question: How is Atorvastatin 30mg coded in Seq#10207 (Discharge Medication Dose)
answer:
Please select ‘Moderate Intensity Dose’.  

To clarify: When a statin dosage is “in-between” intensity levels, code the lower intensity selection.  In this scenario, Atorvastatin 30mg does not meet the definition for ‘High Intensity Dose’; therefore, it is coded as 'Moderate Intensity Dose'.

element_name: Q1a: Difficulty walking indoors on level ground
definition: Indicate the patient's response to the Seattle Angina Questionnaire (SAQ) Question 1a "Over the past four weeks, as a result of your angina, how much difficulty have you had in: walking indoors on level ground?"
question: As there are no coding instructions/data definitions, please explain how the Optional Section: Seattle Angina Questionnaire (SAQ) is to be abstracted.
answer: The SAQ (Seattle Anginal Questionnaire) is a questionnaire, and as such does not have an interpretive guide. Patients are to complete the questionnaire, providing their response to the questions poised.

definition:
Indicate the systolic blood pressure  in mmHg.
 
Note(s):  
Code the first systolic blood pressure obtained in the cath lab procedure room.
question: What blood pressure collection methods are acceptable to use when coding for Seq#6016 (Systolic BP)?
answer: Seq#6016 (Systolic BP) captures the first measurement of blood pressure when the patient enters the cath lab room by non-invasive methods (i.e BP Cuff).  If a systolic BP is not available, please leave this data element blank.

definition:
Indicate if the patient was prescribed or received the medication.

Note(s):
Code 'No' if a patient was given a sublingual, IV, or short acting formula of one of these medications.

Code 'Yes' if the patient received an oral (long-acting formula) of the medication after admission but prior to this cath lab visit.
question: What is the minimum dose of Aspirin needed to code "Yes" to Seq#6991 (Pre-Procedure Medications Administered) for Aspirin?
answer: The minimum dose of Aspirin is at least 75mg to support coding "Yes".

definition:
Indicate the type of procedure performed in conjunction with a diagnostic coronary angiography and/or PCI procedure.

Note(s):
The procedure(s) collected in your application is controlled by Procedure Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: Is a 'groin' shot considered a concomitant procedure in Seq#7066 (Concomitant Procedures Performed Type)?
answer: No.  Angiography of an access site for purpose of anatomical reference or possible closure device placement is considered part of the qualifying procedure (Diagnostic Cath/PCI).  It is not a concomitant procedure.

definition: Indicate the lesion location using the coronary artery segment diagram of the graft lesion.
question: How do I code the segment number for a graft vessel with >=50% stenosis?
answer: If the target lesion is in a bypass graft, indicate the segment location of the first anastomosis distal to the lesion (and if it's above a Y graft, indicate the segment location of the most important distal vessel)

definition:
Indicate if the PCI procedure was performed in the presence of multi-vessel disease.

Note(s):
Code 'Yes' if this is the initial (first) PCI procedure for the cath lab indication and the patient has obstructive disease >=70% stenosis in >=2 coronary vessels and/or disease 50%-70% stenosis in >=2 coronary vessels with non-invasive or FFR/IFR evidence of ischemia in that territory and/or left main disease >=50% stenosis.
(A coronary vessel is defined as: LAD and any of its branches, LCX and any of its branches, RCA and any of its branches, a true RAMUS branch >2 mm)

Code 'Yes' if this is a subsequent, planned staged PCI procedure of a vessel not treated during the initial PCI procedure.  The first PCI could have been during a prior admission, or during this admission but must occur within 90 days of the initial PCI procedure.
question: Can you please clarify what constitutes "Multi-Vessel Disease"?
answer:
To accurately capture Multi-vessel disease, please make the following amendments to the coding instructions in your data dictionary.      Notes(s):  Code "Yes" if this is the initial (first) PCI procedure for the cath lab indication and the patient has obstructive disease >= 70% stenosis in >= 2 coronary vessels and/or disease 50 - 70% stenosis in >=2 coronary vessels with non-invasive or FFR/IFR evidence of ischemia in that territory and/or left main disease >= 50% stenosis.  

 
We anticipate these errors will be corrected in the data dictionary in the next version upgrade.

definition: Indicate the Syntax Score for the PCI procedure.
question: Which SYNTAX score tool should be used to complete Seq#7831 (Syntax Score)?
answer: Physicians/LIP are to use the SYNTAX score 1 tool when calculating the SYNTAX score.  The score can be mapped to the appropriate selection (low, medium or high) using the Data Dictionary definitions for these selections.  A physician/LIP estimate of the SYNTAX score will also support coding.

definition:
Indicate the pre-intervention TIMI flow.

Note(s):  If a lesion spans multiple segments with different TIMI flow, code the lowest TIMI flow within the entire lesion.
question: Can we use the Qualitative/Quantitative Crosswalk to code TIMI Flow in Seq#8007 TIMI Flow (Pre-Intervention)?
answer: No.        The Qualitative Quantitative Crosswalk is singularly designed to assist with coding the stenosis observed in the coronary anatomy when descriptive terms are used to describe it in the medical record.  The Data Dictionary does not provide any assistance with converting descriptive terms to a percent stenosis and this document is designed to fill that gap.  The Qualitative Quantitative Crosswalk is not designed for any other purpose and most specifically should not be used to extrapolate the TIMI flow.  The Data Dictionary provides a definition for each TIMI flow selection.  Thus, when descriptive terms are used to describe the TIMI flow in the medical record, the dictionary definition can be used to accurately select the applicable TIMI flow.

definition: Indicate the date the lesion was previously treated.
question: If the patient's lesion was previously treated and "Yes" is coded in Seq#8008 (Previously Treated Lesion), and the date and year are unknown, how is Seq#8009 (Date)  coded?
answer:
When the date is unknown, it can be left blank.  However, this may affect passing the DQR.  When capturing historical data for data elements that require a date, and the month/day is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/yyyy.  If the year is unknown, it is acceptable to code 01/01/estimated year.  

This guidance is applicable to all data elements capturing historical data.

definition:
Indicate the post-intervention TIMI flow.

Note(s): 
If a lesion spans multiple segments with  different TIMI flows, coded the lowest TIMI flow within the entire lesion.
question: Can we use the Qualitative/Quantitative Crosswalk to code TIMI Flow in Seq#8026 TIMI Flow (Post-Intervention)?
answer: No.    The Qualitative Quantitative Crosswalk is singularly designed to assist with coding the stenosis observed in the coronary anatomy when descriptive terms are used to describe it in the medical record.  The Data Dictionary does not provide any assistance with converting descriptive terms to a percent stenosis and this document is designed to fill that gap.  The Qualitative Quantitative Crosswalk is not designed for any other purpose and most specifically should not be used to extrapolate the TIMI flow.  The Data Dictionary provides a definition for each TIMI flow selection.  Thus, when descriptive terms are used to describe the TIMI flow in the medical record, the dictionary definition can be used to accurately select the applicable TIMI flow.

definition:
Indicate the date and time the patient was discharged from your facility as identified in the medical record.

Note(s): 
Indicate the time (hours:minutes) using the military 24-hour clock, beginning at midnight (00:00 hours). 

If the exact discharge time is not specified in the medical record, then code the appropriate time as below.

0000 - 0559 (midnight to before 6AM) code  0300
0600 - 1159 (6AM - before noon) code 0900
1200 - 1759 (noon before 6PM) code 1500
1800 - 2359 (6PM to before midnight) code 2100
question: When a patient expires, should the date/time of death be used to code Seq#10101 (Discharge Date/Time)?
answer:
Yes.  Please code the patient’s date/time of death in Seq#10101 (Discharge Date/Time). However, if the patient expires in the cath lab, please code Seq# 10101 as one minute after the time coded in Seq# 7005 (Procedure End Date/Time). 



Additional Information,

For patients who are organ donor code the date and time the organs are harvested for Sequence # 10101 (Discharge Date and Time)

definition: Indicate the patient's latest dyspnea or functional class, coded as the New York Heart Association (NYHA) classification.
question: A patient has a documented history of heart failure and "Yes" is coded in Seq#4001 (Heart Failure).  Please clarify how Seq#4011 (NYHA Classification) would be coded when there is no documentation of current symptoms or NYHA Class.
answer:
Please code "NYHA Class I".  To clarify, Seq#4011 (New York Heart Association Classification) can be coded based on physician diagnosis of the NYHA Classification (i.e. NYHA Class II) or on descriptive documentation that meets the definition in the data dictionary. It seeks to capture the "last value" between birth and current procedure.  When there is no NYHA classification or documentation to support coding prior to the procedure, please code the least limiting "Class I".


Exception:  Patients that are receiving positive airway pressure (i.e. BiPAP) or are intubated secondary to a state of acute heart failure are understood to be “unable to carry on any physical activity without discomfort”, meeting the definition of NYHA “Class IV”

element_name: Cardiac Arrest at Transferring Healthcare Facility
definition: Indicate if the patient had cardiac arrest at the transferring healthcare facility prior to arrival at the current facility.
question: When a patient suffers cardiac arrest at an urgent care clinic and is then transferred to my facility, how is Seq# 4635 (Cardiac Arrest at Transferring Healthcare Facility) coded?
answer:
"Yes" is coded in Seq# 4635 (Cardiac Arrest at Transferring Healthcare Facility) for the patient that experienced cardiac arrest at urgent care. 


To clarify: The intent of Seq# 4635 is to capture cardiac arrest that occurs at any healthcare facility, including acute care hospitals, free standing EDs, urgent care, doctor's offices, rehabilitation centers, etc..)

definition:
Indicate the patient symptoms or condition prompting the cath lab visit.

Note(s): 
The Cath Lab Indications collected in this field by your application are controlled by Cath Lab Indication Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: Under what circumstances may ‘Stable Known CAD’ be coded in Seq#7400 (Indication(s) for Cath Lab Visit)?
answer:
‘Stable Known CAD’ is coded when a patient has known coronary artery disease >= 50% in at least one vessel (from a previous diagnostic cath OR ‘Obstructive CAD’ on Cardiac CTA) and they are stable (meaning they are not experiencing ACS symptoms and are not hemodynamically unstable).  

This would be inclusive of patients with a history of interventions (CABG, PCI) or newly identified CAD (meeting the definition).  The patient may/may not be experiencing angina; if so, then the angina must be stable (without any change in frequency or pattern for the six weeks prior to this cath lab presentation).

definition: Indicate the results of the cardiac CTA.
question: Can we utilize the Qualitative Quantitative Crosswalk when there are descriptive terms in the CTA Results Report but % stenosis is not available for Seq#5227 (Cardiac CTA results)?
answer: Yes.  In addition to providing support for capturing % stenosis in Section H. Coronary Anatomy and Section J. Lesions and Devices, the Qualitative Quantitative Crosswalk may be used to support coding Seq#5227 (CTA Results) and Seq#5265 (Prior Dx Coronary Angiography Results).

definition:
Indicate the cardiac valve regurgitation severity.

Note(s): When a range is provided, code the highest value
question: What is coded for Seq#7456 (Valvular Disease Regurgitation Severity) when the documentation states “trace”?
answer:
The registry agrees the following words, trace and trivial, are reflective of "mild" regurgitation and will support coding Seq#7456 (Valvular Disease Regurgitation Severity).  


Additional Information:   The Valvular Disease portion of Section G. (Seq#'s 7450/7451/7455/7456), as with the parent field (Seq# 7400), is coded to reflect documentation/information that is known 'prior' to the start of the procedure.

definition:
Indicate the best estimate of the most severe percent stenosis in the segment of the native coronary vessel identified.

Note(s):

It is acceptable to use prior cath lab visit information, as long as there have been no changes in coronary anatomy. This includes stenosis determined via cardiac catheterization at another facility. This does not include collaterals.

Stenosis represents the percentage diameter reduction, ranging from 0 to 100, associated with the identified vessels. Percent stenosis at its maximal point is estimated to be the amount of reduction in the diameter of the "normal" reference vessel proximal to the lesion. In instances where multiple lesions are present, enter the single highest percent stenosis noted
question: How is Seq#7508 coded when a 60% lesion is identified during the diagnostic portion but has a plaque shift during PCI, resulting in an 80% obstruction.
answer:
Please code "80%" in Seq#7508, capturing the most severe percent stenosis identified during the procedure, per the coding instructions. The procedure is understood to include the diagnostic and PCI portions and is reflective of all events that transpire during the cath lab visit, meeting the target value of last value between 6 months prior to procedure and current procedure


To clarify:
When capturing stenosis percentage in Section H. Coronary Anatomy and adhering to the target value of "last value", it may be necessary to code a different value than what was originally identified during the diagnostic portion of the procedure, such as instances where a stenosis worsens during PCI (i.e. plaque shift).

definition:
Indicate if any graft vessel had a lesion >= 50%.

Note(s):
Identify the disease found in vessels >=2mm.

Identify disease found in vessels <2mm when PCI is intended for the lesion and/or the patients anatomy is <2m.

It is acceptable to use prior cath lab visit information, as long as there have been no changes in coronary anatomy. This includes stenosis determined via cardiac catheterization at another facility. This does not include collaterals.

Stenosis represents the percentage diameter reduction, ranging from 0 to 100, associated with the identified vessels. Percent stenosis at its maximal point is estimated to be the amount of reduction in the diameter of the "normal" reference vessel proximal to the lesion. In instances where multiple lesions are present, enter the single highest percent stenosis noted.
question: How is Seq#7525 (Graft Vessel with Stenosis >= 50% coded) when the physician documents an 80% stenosis but does not indicate the location/anastomosis site of the graft?
answer:
Please code "Yes" in Seq#7525 (Graft Vessel with Stenosis >= 50%) when a graft vessel has a lesion >= 50% and meets the target value.  Seq#7527 (Graft Lesion Segment Number) and Seq#7528 (Graft Stenosis) are left blank when the lesion segment is not identified and clarification is not possible.




Please note the CathPCI Registry does accept documentation of a provider's 'estimate' of the anastomosis site to support coding Seq#7527 (Graft Lesion Segment Number).

definition: Indicate the post-procedure creatinine level in mg/dL. If more than one level is available, code the peak level.
question: Please clarify how the target value for Seq#8510 (Post-Procedure Creatinine) is to be interpreted.
answer:
The target value for Seq#8510 (Post-Procedure Creatinine) provides guidance on how to code post-procedure creatinine when the patient has multiple specimens (code the highest value) and how to accommodate multiple post-procedure scenarios.  The “or” statements identify what should be applied based on the events that occur. 
To clarify:
• Code the highest value between END OF current procedure and 5 days after END OF current procedure. 
• (if a next procedure occurs within 5 days then)	Code the highest value between END OF current procedure and next procedure. 
• (if the patient is discharged within 5 days then) Code the highest value between END OF current procedure and discharge.
If a post-procedure creatinine specimen does not meet one of these parameters, then please code specimen as ‘Not Drawn’ and review Seq#10060 (Discharge Creatinine) to evaluate whether the specimen can be captured there.
Additional Clarification:  The registry’s intent in collecting post-procedure lab values (e.g. Troponin, Creatinine, Hemoglobin) is to reflect the patient’s clinical status with lab work drawn after the end of the procedure.

definition:
Indicate if there was written documentation of a referral for the patient (by the physician, nurse, or other personnel) to an outpatient cardiac rehabilitation program, or a documented medical or patient-centered reason why such a referral was not made.

The program may include a traditional cardiac rehabilitation program based on face-to-face interactions and training sessions or may include other options such as home-based approaches.
question: Our cardiac rehabilitation program has closed; therefore, referrals aren’t being provided to patients.  Can we code ‘No – Health Care System Reason Documented’ for Seq#10116?
answer: Because each patient should be counselled individually the registry expectation is there will be documentation in the medical record explaining why cardiac referral wasn’t provided.  If the rationale is the CR program has closed, ‘No Health Care Reason Documented’ may be selected.  If there is no documentation in the patient’s record discussing why a cardiac referral wasn’t provided, please code ‘No- Reason Not Documented’.

element_name: New Antiarrhythmic Therapy Initiated Prior to Cath Lab
definition:
Indicate if the patient received a NEW antiarrhythmic therapy PRIOR to evaluation within the cath lab.

Note(s):
New Antiarrhythmic therapy is defined as initiation of a new drug to the patient for the purpose of controlling an abnormal rhythm.
question: Is "Yes" coded in Seq#5033 (New Antiarrhythmic Therapy Initiated Prior to Cath Lab) when a patient is administered atropine for their symptomatic bradycardia one day prior to their procedure?
answer:
No.  New antiarrhythmic therapy is defined as initiation of a new drug to the patient for the purposes of CONTROLLING an abnormal rhythm. When the patient is experiencing an 'abnormal rhythm' and a medication is given IV push/bolus (i.e. atropine, lidocaine, magnesium, adenosine, etc.), it is 'treating' , but not 'controlling' the abnormal rhythm.

When the medication is given po, IV infusion/continuous drip (i.e. Cardizem drip, amiodarone drip, lidocaine drip, po digoxin, po Cardizem, etc.) it is treating AND CONTROLLING the abnormal rhythm.

element_name: Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure Results
definition: Indicate the results of the prior diagnostic coronary angiography.
question: When a diagnostic coronary angiogram reveals occluded native vessels but patent grafts, how is Seq#5265 (Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure Results) coded?
answer:
Both ‘Obstructive CAD’ and ‘Non-obstructive CAD’ are coded in this scenario as it is "Select All that Apply."  

To clarify:  Evidence of  occluded native vessel(s) meets the defintion for "Obstructive CAD".  Evidence of patent graft vessel(s) meets the defintion for "Non-Obsructive CAD".   Per the Qualitative Quantitative Crosswalk, documentation of "patent" is equated to a stenosis less than 50%.

definition:
Indicate all devices utilized during the current procedure.  If a device was utilized on multiple lesions, specify it only once (e.g., if a balloon was used to dilate two separate lesions, list it only once). Every treatment and support device utilized during the procedure should be specified.

Note(s): 
Each intracoronary device must be associated with at least one lesion via the Lesion Counter (Element Ref# 8000) if Device Deployed (8024) is 'Yes'.  An intracoronary device may be associated with more than one lesion.

The device(s) collected in this field are controlled by the Intracoronary Device Master file. This file is maintained by the NCDR and will be made available on the internet for downloading and importing/updating into your application.
question: When an angioplasty balloon or stent is advanced over a wire but unable to be deployed, is it captured in Section J. Lesions and Devices?
answer: No.  Please only capture devices in Seq#8028 (Intracoronary Devices Used) that were used in the manner in which they were intended (e.g balloon-inflated, stent-placed, thrombectomy device - aspiration, etc.)  For the given scenario, when a balloon is not inflated or stent is not deployed, it would not be captured.

definition:
Indicate the event that occurred between the procedure and the next procedure or discharge.

Note(s): Multiple instances of the same event may be identified if the event occurred more than once during the target timeframe.
question: How is Seq#9001 (Intra/Post-Procedure Events) coded when a covered stent is required to repair a femoral artery perforation caused by Impella insertion, and the perforated artery is different from the percutaneous access site?
answer:
Please code "Yes" in Seq#9001 (Intra/Post-Procedure Events) for "Bleeding: Other".  The femoral artery perforation is understood to represent evidence of an observed/documented bleed and the covered stent qualifies as a procedural intervention at the bleeding site to correct the bleeding.  Therefore, the definition is met.

Additional Clarification:  "Other Vascular Complication Requiring Treatment" would not qualify for capture as this selection is specific to complications at the percutaneous entry site, as coded in Seq#7320 (Arterial Access Site).

definition:
Indicate if the heart failure was newly diagnosed.

Note: Code 'Yes' (newly diagnosed) if there is no documentation of a prior diagnosis of heart failure.
question: How is Seq# 4012 (Heart Failure Newly Diagnosed) coded when a patient presents to hospital A with newly-diagnosed heart failure, but transfers to hospital B?
answer:
If the patient's first-ever diagnosis of heart failure occurs at hospital A and they are transferred to hospital B for cardiac treatment, code 'Yes' for Seq #4012 at hospital B.
If the patient's first-ever diagnosis of heart failure occurs at hospital A and PCI is performed, then the patient is subsequently transferred to hospital B for continuation of cardiac care, code 'No' for Seq# 4012 at hospital B.

definition:
Indicate the best estimate of the most severe percent stenosis in the segment of the graft vessel identified.

Note(s):
It is acceptable to use prior cath lab visit information, as long as there have been no changes in coronary anatomy. This includes stenosis determined via cardiac catheterization at another facility. This does not include collaterals.

Stenosis represents the percentage diameter reduction, ranging from 0 to 100, associated with the identified vessels. Percent stenosis at its maximal point is estimated to be the amount of reduction in the diameter of the "normal" reference vessel proximal to the lesion. In instances where multiple lesions are present, enter the single highest percent stenosis noted.
question: When a physician describes a bypass graft as atretic without a percent stenosis, how do we capture this in Seq# 7528 (Graft Coronary Vessel Stenosis)?
answer: The term 'atretic' cannot be correlated to a percent stenosis for the purpose of the registry nor is it listed in the Qualitative Quantitative Crosswalk; therefore, a numeric assignment cannot be coded for Seq# 7528 (Graft Coronary Vessel Stenosis). Please clarify with the physician a percent stenosis and amend the medical record as necessary to support data capture.

element_name: Emergency Department Presentation at Referring Facility Date and Time
definition:
Code the date and time of arrival to the original, transferring facility as documented in the medical record.

Note(s):
Indicate the time (hours:minutes) using the military 24-hour clock, beginning at midnight (00:00 hours).
question: How is Seq #7842 (Emergency Department Presentation at Referring Facility Date and Time) coded when there is no ED visit at the referring facility, but rather the patient was an inpatient who subsequently experienced STEMI?
answer: Please code the date and time the patient arrived at the transferring facility for Seq #7842 (Emergency Department Presentation at Referring Facility Date and Time) for this scenario.

definition:
Indicate the event that occurred between the procedure and the next procedure or discharge.

Note(s): Multiple instances of the same event may be identified if the event occurred more than once during the target timeframe.
question: When is ‘Myocardial Infarction’ identified as an intra- or post-procedural event for Seq# 9001, in the absence of biomarkers?
answer:
Myocardial Infarction is coded ‘Yes’ for Seq# 9001 (Intra/Post-Procedure Events) whenever there is a NEW obstruction, that results in NEW patient symptoms of ischemia and/or ST elevation that without treatment would result in loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality. 



Example: The cath procedure is in progress and there is a NEW plaque shift, thrombus, dissection, etc. that was not present at the start AND requires immediate intervention (i.e., PCI in progress for mid-LAD lesion and plaque shift occludes the 1st diagonal).

question: Should data elements that require a “value” (ex. height, weight, DAP, Creatinine, etc.) be “rounded”?
answer:
No.  Numerical values captured throughout the data set are truncated to the decimal place as defined in the technical specifications for that specific data element.  Please do not round.

Examples:

Troponin - 6.818 ng/ml - hundredths place per Technical Specification = 6.81
Weight - 68.876 Kg - hundredths place per Technical Specification = 68.87 
DAP - 2084.66 uGy/M2 - whole number per Technical Specification = 2084

definition:
Indicate if the patient has had at least one documented previous myocardial infarction.

Note(s): 
Code 'No' if the patient's only MI occurred at the transferring facility.

 Code 'Yes' if the patient's only MI occurred at the transferring facility but it was treated with PCI or CABG prior to arrival at this facility
question: Please clarify if a ‘fixed perfusion defect’ is noted on a stress test result, does this support coding “Yes” to Seq# 4291 (Prior MI)?
answer: A “fixed defect” is accepted by the registry as conclusive evidence of a prior MI.  To clarify - Any defect that is described as an “irreversible perfusion defect” is also evidence of a prior MI, and would support coding ‘Yes’ to Seq# 4291 (Prior MI) with the understanding that the target value “any occurrence between birth and arrival at this facility” is met.

definition:
Indicate if the patient was prescribed or received the medication.

Note(s):
Code 'No' if a patient was given a sublingual, IV, or short acting formula of one of these medications.

Code 'Yes' if the patient received an oral (long-acting formula) of the medication after admission but prior to this cath lab visit.
question: Provider documentation indicates Lipitor is contraindicated for the patient and no other statin medications have been prescribed.   How are “Statins” coded in Seq# 6991 (PreProcedure Medication Administered)?
answer: Please code “Contraindicated” for “Statins”.  A documented medical reason (e.g. allergy, adverse drug interaction) for not prescribing one pre-procedure medication applies to the entire medication class.

definition: Indicate the total fluoroscopy time recorded to the nearest 0.1-minute.  The time recorded should include the total time for the lab visit.
question: For Seq# 7214 (Fluoroscopy Time), the time recorded for the procedure is 14.56.  The coding instructions state to indicate the time recorded to the nearest 0.1 minute - am I supposed to round up and code “14.6”?
answer: No.  This value is truncated according to the decimal place as defined in the technical specifications.  Consequently, the value recorded is “14.5”.  Please do not round.

definition: Indicate the total fluoroscopy dose to the nearest integer. The value recorded should include the total dose for the lab visit.
question: For Seq# 7220 (Dose Area Product), the dose recorded for the procedure is 48.7.  The coding instructions state to indicate the total fluoroscopy dose to the “nearest integer”.  Am I supposed to round up and code “49”?
answer: No.  The value is truncated.  “Nearest Integer” is understood by the registry to be the number that appears before the decimal point.  Therefore, a value of “48.7” is coded as “48”.

definition:
Indicate the Troponin I result in ng/mL.
 
Note(s): 
This may include POC (Point of Care) testing results.
question: The target value for Seq#6090 (Pre-Procedure Troponin I) is 'the last value between the date of arrival and current procedure'.  Does this mean I can capture a pre-procedure troponin value drawn at the transferring facility on the date the patient arrives at my facility?
answer: No.  The target value for Seq#6090 (Pre-Procedure Troponin I) and Seq#6095 (Pre-Procedure Troponin T) should be interpreted as the last value between date of arrival 'at this facility' and current procedure.  Troponin values obtained prior to arrival are not captured.

definition:
Indicate if the procedure involved a crossover to a different access site.

Note(s):
Code 'Yes' when the final procedure access site is subsequent to where arterial access for the procedure was first attempted.
question: The patient is having a PCI to treat a Chronic Total Occlusion (CTO) and two separate arterial access sites are purposely obtained per the documented plan.   Is "Yes" coded in Seq#7325 (Arterial crossover)?
answer: Please code "No" to Seq#7325 (Arterial Cross Over) in this scenario. This data element captures scenarios when one access site is initially obtained and then for various reasons, a separate access site is obtained to finish the procedure. 'Planned' dual access sites are not considered arterial cross overs.

element_name: Decision for PCI with Surgical Consult
definition: Indicate if a cardiac surgical consult was obtained prior to engaging in PCI.
question: How is Seq#7815 (Decision for PCI with Surgical Consult) coded when a patient had a cardiac surgical consult prior to arrival for this episode of care?
answer: Please code "Yes" as a surgical consult was obtained that informed the decision for this PCI procedure.  This meets the target value of “the value on current procedure”.

element_name: STEMI or STEMI Equivalent First Noted
definition:
Indicate if a STEMI or STEMI equivalent was noted on either the first ECG or a subsequent ECG.

Note(s):
Code "Subsequent ECG" if STEMI is noted after the ECG on arrival does not indicate STEMI or STEMI equivalent.

Code "Subsequent ECG" if STEMI is noted on an ECG subsequent to the patients non-cardiac presentation.

Code "Subsequent ECG" if STEMI is noted on an inpatient ECG.
question: How is Seq#7835 (STEMI or STEMI Equivalent First Noted) coded when an ECG performed by EMS is positive for STEMI?
answer:
Please use the following guidance:


•	When an EMS ECG is definitive for STEMI and moves the patient to the cath lab, please code "First ECG"


•	In scenarios where EMS performs multiple ECG's and a 'Subsequent' ECG is definitive for STEMI, this is STILL coded as the "First ECG".


•	IF EMS does not have a definitive ECG for STEMI, then ALL ECG's obtained prior to arrival are NOT considered for the CathPCI Registry and the "First ECG" obtained at your facility is coded.

definition:
Indicate if the stenosis is considered to be responsible for the acute coronary syndrome.

Note(s): 
Code 'No' if the stenosis is not considered to be responsible for the evidence of ischemia.
question: A patient with NSTEMI presents for their cardiac cath and a 90% lesion in the pRCA is identified and treated with a DES. Can “Yes” be coded in Seq# 8002 (Culprit Stenosis) for the pRCA lesion? The documentation does not specifically state it is the culprit.
answer:
Yes.  When only one lesion receives mechanical revascularization, it is understood that the lesion is the 'culprit’ and supports coding “Yes” in Seq# 8002 (Culprit Stenosis). 
Additional Information:
When multiple lesions receive mechanical revascularization, a single ‘culprit’ lesion cannot be assumed, because it is possible more than one lesion is responsible for the patient’s symptoms. 
 In these scenarios, the culprit lesion must be specifically identified/documented to support coding ‘Yes’ in Seq#8002 (Culprit Stenosis).

definition: Indicate if the patient has been diagnosed with heart failure.
question: How are the history and risk factors data elements completed for patients with a heart transplant?
answer:
Reflect the history of the "new" heart in:

•  Seq# 4001 (Heart Failure)

•  Seq# 4291 (Prior MI)


Reflect the patient’s lifetime history with CAD in the below data elements and all others in this section:

•  Seq#4515 (Prior CABG) 

•  Seq#4995 (Prior PCI)

element_name: Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure without intervention
definition:
Indicate if the patient had a prior diagnostic coronary angiography procedure without a subsequent intervention.

Note(s): 
Code “No” if the patient's previous diagnostic coronary angiogram occurred at the transferring facility and the patient presents for PCI.

Code "No"  if the most recent cath lab visit involved PCI.
question: How is Seq#5263 (Prior Diagnostic Coronary Angiography Procedure without intervention) completed for patients with a heart transplant?
answer: Complete this data element based on the history of the “new” heart (not the patient’s lifetime history).

definition:
Indicate if the PCI procedure was performed in the presence of multi-vessel disease.

Note(s):
Code 'Yes' if this is the initial (first) PCI procedure for the cath lab indication and the patient has obstructive disease >=70% stenosis in >=2 coronary vessels and/or disease 50%-70% stenosis in >=2 coronary vessels with non-invasive or FFR/IFR evidence of ischemia in that territory and/or left main disease >=50% stenosis.
(A coronary vessel is defined as: LAD and any of its branches, LCX and any of its branches, RCA and any of its branches, a true RAMUS branch >2 mm)

Code 'Yes' if this is a subsequent, planned staged PCI procedure of a vessel not treated during the initial PCI procedure.  The first PCI could have been during a prior admission, or during this admission but must occur within 90 days of the initial PCI procedure.
question: How would Seq#7820 (PCI for Multi-Vessel Disease) be coded for patients with a history of CABG?
answer:
For patients with CABG, the native (un-bypassed vessel or portion of the vessel) and the bypass graft need to be considered when applying the definition of ‘multi-vessel disease’ as discussed below:
<• Obstructive disease >=70% stenosis in >=2 un-bypassed native or bypass vessels and/or
•  Disease 50%-70% in >=2 un-bypassed native or bypass vessels with non-invasive FFR/IFR evidence of ischemia in that territory and/or
•  Left main disease >=50%. 
*If PCI will be attempted and/or performed on a bypassed native, then include it in your count of diseased vessels.

definition:
Indicate other interventions (percutaneous or surgical) that occurred during this hospitalization. 

Note(s): 
This does not include interventions that occurred during the same cath lab visit as a Diagnostic Cath or PCI procedure.
question: What is coded for ‘Other’ in Seq#10030 (Interventions this Hospitalization)?
answer:
This data element is designed to collect surgeries/procedures that occurred during the same hospital stay as a Cath and/or PCI however, outside the cath lab visit. 

Examples of ‘Other’ include but may not be limited to: 
• Peripheral intervention
• Carotid stent
• Surgical repair of arterial access site/non-access site
• Surgical removal/closure of LV mechanical device
• Pericardiocentesis, thoracentesis, paracentesis

definition: Indicate the type of intervention or surgery that occurred.
question: Please expand on the type(s) of surgeries coded as "Surgery (Non-Cardiac)" in Seq#10031 (Interventions this Hospitalization Type)?
answer: The selection "Surgery (Non-Cardiac)" is intended to identify major surgeries that have inherent risk of significant bleeding, morbidity and mortality. Examples include hip replacement, renal transplant, cholecystectomy etc. Please submit an inquiry to the registry if there is any doubt whether a non- cardiac surgery qualifies for this selection.

definition:
Indicate if the procedure involved a crossover to a different access site.

Note(s):
Code 'Yes' when the final procedure access site is subsequent to where arterial access for the procedure was first attempted.
question: A patient presents for PCI and the right radial site is prepped and the artery punctured; however, due to anatomical tortuosity, the sheath cannot be advanced.  Right femoral access is successful and the procedure continued. How is Seq# 7325 (Arterial Cross Over) coded?
answer: Please code “Yes” to Seq# 7325.  Per the ‘Notes’ section of the definition, “Yes” is coded when the final procedure access site is subsequent to where arterial access for the procedure was first ‘attempted’.  Note that any needle puncture of the skin in pursuit of the artery is an “attempt”.

definition: Indicate if the medication was prescribed, not prescribed, or was not prescribed for either a medical or patient reason.
question: Physician documentation at discharge states “No aspirin”.  Is this sufficient to support coding “Not Prescribed - Medical Reason” for aspirin in Seq# 10205 (Discharge Medications Prescribed)?
answer:
No.  Please code "Not Prescribed - No Reason" in the given scenario.  Documentation that ONLY states "No aspirin" would be considered insufficient to support coding "Not Prescribed - Medical Reason."

To code “Not Prescribed - Medical Reason”, there must be clear documentation of a reason related to the patient's medical issue or concern.

Additionally, general documentation of why the medication was not prescribed (such as physician documentation that the “medication was contraindicated” without specifying the exact contraindication) also supports coding “Not Prescribed – Medical Reason.”

definition: Indicate if the medication was prescribed, not prescribed, or was not prescribed for either a medical or patient reason.
question: Physician documentation indicates that the patient will not be discharged on atorvastatin, secondary to elevated liver enzymes.  Is this sufficient to support coding “Not Prescribed - Medical Reason” for ALL statins in Seq# 10205 (Discharge Medications Prescribed)?
answer: Yes.  It is understood that a documented contraindication to one medication applies to the entire class of medications.

question: A patient has no documented h/o hypertension... How is Seq# 4615 (Hypertension) coded?
answer: No
rationale: Without a documented diagnosis of hypertension, even elevated BP values do not meet criteria for coding 'Yes' for hypertension.

question: There is no documentation of dyslipidemia... How is Seq 4620 (Dyslipidemia) coded?
answer: No
rationale: Elevated labs alone aren't sufficient. Must have documentation of diagnosis or treatment by a provider.

question: Patient has history of use of a statin... Is this sufficient to capture seq 4620 as 'yes' for dyslipidemia?
answer: Yes
rationale: Evidence of treatment (e.g., statin use) satisfies the requirement even without an explicit diagnosis.

question: Patient is at Hospital A with an MI... How is Seq# 4291 (Previous MI) coded for Hospital B?
answer: Yes
rationale: If treated with PCI or CABG at Hospital A, it's considered history and should be coded 'Yes' at Hospital B.

question: Patient does not have a history of DM... Would we code 'yes’ for Seq# 4555 (Diabetes)?
answer: No
rationale: Without a diagnosis, even use of insulin in ICU is not sufficient.

question: Patient arrived at the ED with no prior medical hx... how is Seq# 4551 (Cerebrovascular Disease) coded?
answer: No
rationale: Diagnosis occurred after arrival, does not meet target value for 'history'.

question: Pt admitted w/NSTEMI... Carotid ultrasound showed <50% stenosis... how is Seq# 4551 coded?
answer: Yes
rationale: Provider documentation of 'history of carotid artery disease' supports coding despite imaging.

question: Patient has history of ischemic finger and toe and rest pain... Is this documentation enough for Seq# 4610?
answer: Yes
rationale: Documented history of atherosclerosis in extremities supports coding PAD.

question: Documentation states patient is experiencing claudication... but study does not show significant PAD. How is Seq# 4610 coded?
answer: Yes
rationale: Claudication symptoms alone can support coding even if test does not confirm stenosis.

question: Pt has hx of asthma... Would we be able to code 'yes' to Seq# 4576 (Chronic Lung Disease)?
answer: No
rationale: Asthma is not included under chronic lung disease per supporting definition.

question: What is considered as 'Other' in Seq#10031 (Interventions this Hospitalization Type)?
answer: Surgeries or procedures outside the cath lab during same hospital stay.
rationale: E.g., peripheral intervention, carotid stent, surgical repairs.

question: Please expand on the type(s) of surgeries coded as 'Surgery (Non-Cardiac)' in Seq#10031?
answer: Major surgeries with bleeding or mortality risk.
rationale: E.g., hip replacement, renal transplant. Clarify with registry if unsure.

question: How would Seq#7820 (PCI for Multi-Vessel Disease) be coded for patients with CABG?
answer: Include both bypass and unbypassed vessels.
rationale: Criteria include obstructive disease, ischemia, or left main disease.

data_field: PCI for Residual Stenosis from Prior Angiography
question: How is Seq#5263 coded for patients with a heart transplant?
answer: Based on the history of the new heart
rationale: not lifetime history.

question: How are history/risk factors coded for heart transplant patients?
answer: New heart history applies to MI and HF
rationale: Lifetime history applies to prior CABG and PCI.

question: When is MI identified for Seq# 9001 in absence of biomarkers?
answer: When there's a new obstruction causing ischemia/ST elevation/regional wall motion abnormality
rationale: Needing immediate intervention.

question: Patient had PCI, developed new thrombus post-procedure... How is MI Seq# 9001 coded for the 1st cath?
answer: Yes
rationale: New thrombus, ST elevation, ischemia all support coding MI as intra/post-procedure event.

question: ST elevation occurred during balloon inflation... How is MI coded for Seq# 9001?
answer: No
rationale: Transient ischemia due to inflation doesn't count unless it's from a new obstruction.

question: PCI attempted but unsuccessful... Provider documents 'Not appropriate for cardiac rehab referral'. How is Seq# 10116 coded?
answer: No – Medical Reason Documented
rationale: Documentation shows provider intent and assessment.

question: Provider documents 'Patient not requiring service to Outpt cardiac rehab'... How is Seq# 10116 coded?
answer: No – Reason Not Documented
rationale: Not requiring' isn't sufficient to indicate it's medically contraindicated.

question: Cardiac rehab referral to be given upon follow-up... Is this enough to support 'No – Medical Reason Documented'?
answer: No – Reason Not Documented
rationale: No valid medical or system reason documented at discharge.

data_field: PCI for Residual Stenosis from Prior Angiography
question: Unable to get clarification on lesion length... total stent length >100mm. How is Seq# 8020 coded?
answer: 100mm
rationale: Abstractor should enter 100mm if total length exceeds 100mm and clarification isn't possible.

question: How is Seq# 5263 coded when patient has PCI after diagnostic cath at same facility within 30 days?
answer: No
rationale: If PCI treats CAD found on recent diagnostic cath and no new status change occurred, code 'No'.

question: A patient with a known history of CAD, presents for surgical clearance prior to a colon resection. She reports that there has been no changes in her symptoms, just the usual chest pain she has on exertion, but which is promptly relieved with rest. ECG and stress testing is performed. Neither revealed any new ischemic changes for the patient. How is Seq# 7800 (PCI Status) coded?
answer: Elective
rationale: Patient has stable angina and no new ischemic changes noted on ECG or stress study.

question: Can you clarify what the registry deems 'ischemic findings' for 7800 ‘Elective’ definition as well? ST elevation/depression or T wave inversions? What if the ECG just says suggestive of ischemia?
answer: If the ECG findings are not clearly documented by a physician/provider
rationale: they should be clarified. Abstractors should not interpret ECGs.

question: The patient presents for their scheduled cath lab procedure and informs the physician that her symptoms have been increasing in frequency and duration requiring more nitroglycerin to obtain relief. Will the change in patient symptoms be captured in Seq# 7800 (PCI Status)?
answer: Yes, Urgent should be selected.
rationale: Patient's symptoms have increased in frequency and severity since scheduling.

question: Patient has new-onset angina which began an hour prior to alerting EMS. During transport, nitroglycerin and morphine were administered without relief. ECG revealed ‘borderline’ ST-elevation. Upon arrival to the ER, repeat ECG positive for STEMI and patient immediately brought to cath lab for evaluation/treatment. How is Seq# 7800 (PCI Status) coded?
answer: Emergency
rationale: Acute symptoms with cardiovascular instability requiring immediate procedure.

question: Patient presents to the ED and is diagnosed with ACS/NSTEMI. A Nitro drip is started for ongoing angina and a heart cath is scheduled for the next day. On arrival to the Cath Lab, angina is being controlled with the Nitro drip. How do we code #7800 PCI Status for this case?
answer: Urgent
rationale: Symptoms are not stable, but treatment is controlling them and procedure not performed without delay.

question: If a patient is an outpatient coming in for a Cath/PCI, will they always be considered 'elective' as this is what was communicated to me in the past?
answer: No
rationale: PCI Status is based on symptoms/condition, not admission status or physical location.

question: Patient is admitted with complaints of increasing anginal symptoms and is scheduled to have Cath/PCI several days after admission. How is Seq# 7800 (PCI Status) coded?
answer: Urgent
rationale: Worsening angina prior to cath lab presentation.

question: Related to the prior scenario of a patient admitted with increasing angina symptoms and is scheduled to have Cath/PCI several days after admission. On arrival to the cath lab, the patient has not experienced angina within the past 24 hours. How is Seq# 7800 (PCI Status) coded?
answer: Urgent
rationale: Symptoms were worsening prior to presentation, even if stable in the last 24 hours.

question: What types of surgeries or procedures are captured as ‘Other’ in Seq#10031 (Interventions this Hospitalization type)?
answer: Examples include peripheral intervention, carotid stent, access/non-access site surgical repairs, etc.
rationale: (No additional rationale)

question: Post PCI the patient was found to have a perforation with extravasation in the right CFA (percutaneous access site). The femoral artery access site perforation was stented, there was no drop in hemoglobin and no transfusions were administered. How are Seq# 9001/9002 coded for this scenario?
answer: Other Vascular Complications Requiring Treatment
rationale: (No additional rationale)

question: In the prior scenario of a vascular complication that required stenting of the femoral artery, how is Seq# 10030/10031 (Interventions the Hospitalization /Type) coded?
answer: Seq# 10030 = Yes; Seq# 10031 = Other
rationale: (No additional rationale)

data_field: Use of Physiologic Lesion Assessment (e.g., FFR/iFR)
question: Please expand on the type(s) of surgeries coded as 'Surgery (Non-Cardiac)' in Seq#10031 (Interventions this Hospitalization Type)?
answer: Major surgeries with risk of bleeding/morbidity
rationale: e.g., hip replacement, renal transplant, cholecystectomy

question: Our facility began utilizing CathWorks FFR. How do we capture this as an adjunctive measurement?
answer: Seq# 7511 = Yes if measurement used as PCI rationale; Seq# 7513 = '0' for ischemia (≤0.8), '1' if not (>0.8)
rationale: (No additional rationale)

question: Patient was scheduled for a PCI procedure, however, after the wire was introduced, lesion could not be crossed. Physician documents ‘not indicated for rehab’. How is Seq# 10116 coded?
answer: No – Medical Reason Documented
rationale: (No additional rationale)

question: If a patient experienced an intra/post-procedure stroke, how would this be reported on the physician level dashboard when the patient had both a diagnostic coronary angiography and a PCI during separate cath lab visits?
answer: It will be reported for both the Diagnostic Cath and PCI operators.
rationale: (No additional rationale)

content: Seq#7400 Indications for Cath Lab Visit Name Definition The patient has Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) (unstable angina, NSTEMI or STEMI) <= 24 hours prior to cath lab ACS <= 24 hrs presentation. The patient has Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) (unstable angina, NSTEMI or STEMI) > 24 hours prior to cath lab ACS > 24 hrs presentation. (STEMI/NSTEMI <= 7days from symptoms) New Onset Angina <= 2 months The patient has new onset angina (typical or atypical angina), within two months of cath lab presentation. Worsening Angina The patient has a history of angina that has increased in severity or frequency within the last 2 months. Resuscitated Cardiac Arrest The patient presents status post cardiac arrest. Stable Known CAD The patient has known coronary artery disease >= 50% in at least one vessel. Suspected CAD The patient presents for suspected coronary artery disease, there is no prior documentation of CAD >= 50 % in a vessel. The patient has disease of at least one heart valve. Valvular Disease The patient has pericardial disease (an inflammation of the pericardial sac). Pericardial Disease 3 | P a g e Published 8/2017 Updated 1/3/2025 C. Anderson Name Definition The patient has a cardiac arrhythmia (also known as cardiac dysrhythmia or irregular heartbeat, a group of conditions in Cardiac Arrhythmia which the heartbeat is irregular, too fast, or too slow). The patient has cardiomyopathy (disease of the heart muscle). Cardiomyopathy Types of cardiomyopathy include; hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, dilated cardiomyopathy, restrictive cardiomyopathy, arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia and Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The patient has left ventricular (LV) dysfunction. In left-sided or left ventricular heart failure, the left side of the heart LV Dysfunction must work harder to pump the same amount of blood. The two types of LV dysfunction are systolic (reduced ejection fraction -HFrEF) and diastolic (preserved ejection fraction - HFpEF) heart failure. The patient has experienced syncope, a temporary loss of consciousness usually related to insufficient blood flow to the Syncope brain. It’s also called fainting or "passing out". Post Cardiac Transplant The patient has received a cardiac transplant. Pre-operative evaluation The patient requires cardiac evaluation of the coronary arteries and/or LV function. Evaluation for Exercise Clearance The patient presents for clearance to participate in an exercise program or cardiac rehab. Other Not otherwise specified. 4 | P a g e Published 8/2017 Updated 1/3/2025 C. Anderson

Seq#7405 Chest Pain Symptom Assessment Documentation of: Supports coding: Typical Angina  Typical angina  Substernal chest discomfort with characteristic quality/duration that is Symptoms meet all three of the characteristics of angina (also known provoked by exertion or emotional stress and relieved by rest or nitroglycerin as definite):  CCS IV 1. Substernal chest discomfort with a characteristic quality and  Angina with STEMI presentation duration that is  Unstable angina 2. provoked by exertion or emotional stress and 3. relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. Atypical Angina  Atypical angina  Two of the three characteristics of typical angina Symptoms meet two of the three characteristics of typical angina  CCS I, II, III (also known as probable). Non-anginal Chest Pain  Non-anginal chest pain  One of the typical characteristics of angina The patient meets one, or none of the typical characteristics of  Non-ischemic chest pain angina.  Costochondritis  Chest wall pain Asymptomatic  No symptoms, no angina  Asymptomatic No typical or atypical symptoms or non-anginal chest pain.  No complaints of pain Documentation of “anginal equivalent” symptoms are coded as ‘atypical angina’ unless provider documentation identifies they are representative of ‘typical angina’. 5 | P a g e Published 8/2017 Updated 1/3/2025 C. Anderson Section I. PCI Procedure

Seq#7825 Percutaneous Coronary Intervention Indication Name Definition Immediate PCI for STEMI (or STEMI equivalent) - PCI is performed emergently and without delay after STEMI - Immediate PCI for Acute STEMI diagnosis (<12 hrs). PCI for STEMI (or STEMI equivalent) occurs <= 12 hours from symptom. There are no symptoms of recurrent STEMI - Stable (<= 12 hrs from Sx) or persistent ischemia, symptoms of heart failure or electrical instability. STEMI - Unstable (> 12 hrs from Sx) PCI for STEMI (or STEMI equivalent) > 12 hours from symptom with recurrent or persistent symptoms, symptoms of heart failure or ventricular arrhythmia. PCI for STEMI (or STEMI equivalent) after receiving full-dose thrombolysis. There are no symptoms of STEMI (after successful lytics) recurrent or persistent ischemia, symptoms of heart failure or electrical instability. STEMI - Rescue (after unsuccessful lytics) Rescue PCI for STEMI (or STEMI equivalent) after failed full-dose thrombolysis for symptoms of recurrent or persistent ischemia, symptoms of heart failure or electrical instability. Anderson Name Coding Instructions Definition Indicate whether the patient experienced a NEW occurrence of biomarker positive myocardial infarction (at least one determination of biomarkers obtained no sooner than 6 hours after the procedure, preferably within the interval of 6-24 See below hours post-procedure should be used) Myocardial Infarction Notes: Code ‘Yes’ when new Q waves are present with absent, incomplete or inconclusive biomarkers. Code ‘Yes’ when biomarkers are not obtained in the setting of post-PCI acute MI The term acute myocardial infarction (MI) should be used when there is evidence of myocardial necrosis in a clinical setting consistent with acute myocardial ischemia. Under these conditions, any one of the following criteria meets the diagnosis for MI:  Detection of a rise and/or fall of cardiac biomarker values [preferably cardiac troponin (cTn)] with at least one value above the 99th percentile upper reference limit (URL) and with at least one of the following: Symptoms of ischemia o New of presumed new significant ST-segment – T wave (ST-T) changes or new LBBB o Development of pathological Q waves in the ECG o Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality o Identification of an intracoronary thrombus by angiography or autopsy o  Cardiac death with symptoms suggestive of myocardial ischemia and presumed new ischemic ECG changes or new LBBB, but death occurred before cardiac biomarkers were obtained, or before cardiac biomarker values would be increased  PCI related MI is arbitrarily defined by elevation of cTn values (>5 x 99th percentile URL) in patients with normal baseline values (≤99th percentile URL) or a rise of cTn values >20% if the baseline values are elevated and are stable or falling. In addition, either (i) symptoms suggestive of myocardial ischemia or (ii) new ischemia ECG changes or (iii) angiographic findings consistent with a procedural complication or (iv) imaging demonstration of loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality are required  Stent thrombosis associated with MI when detected by coronary angiography or autopsy in the setting of myocardial ischemia and with a risk and/or fall of cardiac biomarker values with at least one value above the 99th percentile URL  CABG related MI is arbitrarily defined by elevation of cardiac biomarker values (>10 x 99th percentile URL) in patients with normal baseline cTn values (≤99th percentile URL). In additional, either (i) new pathological Q waves or new LBB, or (ii) angiographic documented new graft or new native coronary artery occlusion, or (iii) imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality 13 | P a g e Published 8/2017 Updated 1/3/2025 C. Code ‘No’ when signs/symptoms of cardiac instability are not present or actively being managed with pharmacological or mechanical support on arrival to the cath lab. Seq#7800 PCI Status Coding Instruction: Indicate the status of the PCI. The status is determined at the time the operator decides to perform a PCI. Target Value: The highest value at start of current procedure Elective Symptoms of cardiac ischemia have been stable. In the days/weeks prior to cath lab presentation the patient has had: • No angina/ is asymptomatic (i.e., no typical, atypical, nor anginal equivalent symptoms or non-anginal chest pain) OR; • Stable angina – symptoms of angina are consistent for the patient (i.e., without a change in frequency or pattern), and are controlled with rest and/or medication(s) AND; • ECG is normal or unchanged and without new ischemic findings for the patient Urgent Symptoms of cardiac ischemia have not been stable. In the days/weeks prior to cath lab presentation the patient has had: • New angina diagnosis (i.e., typical, atypical or anginal equivalent pain) OR; • Worsening angina (i.e., increase in severity or frequency, more or new medications required) OR; • Related cardiac symptoms (i.e., new diagnosis or heart failure or increasing symptoms requiring medication adjustment, hypo/hypertension requiring treatment). Emergency Symptoms of cardiac ischemia are acute. On Cath Lab presentation the patient has: • Ongoing cardiac ischemia (i.e., typical, atypical angina or anginal equivalent) OR; • Cardiovascular instability (i.e., refractory angina, ST-elevation w/without hemodynamic instability, acute heart failure, hypo/hypertension, or ventricular arrhythmias) OR; • Symptoms of cardiac ischemia/instability are being controlled with ongoing medical management *The procedure should be performed asap/without delay (would warrant activating the on-call team if off-hours or bumping a scheduled case to accommodate) due to concerns for ongoing ischemia and/or infarction and/or risk of death. Salvage Symptoms of cardiac ischemia are acute, and the patient is decompensated. On Cath Lab presentation the patient is in:

• Cardiogenic shock (i.e., at procedure start as coded in Seq#7000) AND has; o Received chest compressions (within 10min before procedure start or during the diagnostic portion of the case) OR; Been placed on unanticipated LV support (e.g., ECMO, CPS, etc.) intra-procedure and prior to PCI guidewire insertion. o APPSUPPORT-25670 – 12/19/2024 23 | P a g e Published 8/2017 Updated 1/3/2025 C. Anderson
